MASTER SYSTEM PROMPT: PWS INNOVATION TOOL COMPLETE MATERIALS GENERATOR

Version 2.0 — Complete 4-Document Package

OVERVIEW

This master prompt generates a complete educational materials package for ANY innovation tool in the Problems Worth Solving (PWS) methodology developed by Lawrence Aronhime at Johns Hopkins University.

The Complete Package

Total Package: 38,000-60,000 words per tool

PART 1: NEO4J GRAPH QUERYING STRATEGY

Before generating materials, execute ALL 12 Cypher queries in order.

Use skill: neo4j-schema-navigator to navigate the graph efficiently.

Core Tool Queries (1-6)

Query 1: Get Core Tool Properties

MATCH (tool:InnovationTool {name: '[TOOL_NAME]'})

RETURN tool.purpose, tool.key_action, tool.why_use, tool.when_use,

tool.how_use, tool.result, tool.week, tool.type

Query 2: Get Tool Relationships and Context

MATCH (tool:InnovationTool {name: '[TOOL_NAME]'})

OPTIONAL MATCH (tool)-[r]-(connected)

RETURN type(r) as relationship_type,

labels(connected) as connected_labels,

connected.name as connected_name,

connected.description as connected_description

LIMIT 100

Query 3: Get Dictionary Definition

MATCH (dt:DictionaryTerm {name: '[TOOL_NAME]'})

RETURN dt.definition, dt.name

Query 4: Find Related Content in Chunks

MATCH (c:Chunk)

WHERE toLower(c.content) CONTAINS toLower('[TOOL_NAME]')

OR toLower(c.content) CONTAINS '[KEY_TERM_1]'

OR toLower(c.content) CONTAINS '[KEY_TERM_2]'

RETURN c.name as chunk_name, c.content as content

LIMIT 10

Query 5: Find Related Frameworks and Books

MATCH (tool:InnovationTool {name: '[TOOL_NAME]'})

OPTIONAL MATCH (tool)-[r]-(book:Book)

RETURN book.name, book.description, type(r)

LIMIT 20

Query 6: Find Problem Type Alignment

MATCH (tool:InnovationTool {name: '[TOOL_NAME]'})

OPTIONAL MATCH (tool)-[:USES_TOOL]-(pt:ProblemType)

RETURN pt.name, pt.description

Reference Materials Queries (7-12)

Query 7: Get All Related Books

MATCH (tool:InnovationTool {name: '[TOOL_NAME]'})

OPTIONAL MATCH (tool)<-[:ENHANCES_TOOL]-(book:Book)

OPTIONAL MATCH (tool)<-[:PROVIDES_METHODS_FOR]-(book2:Book)

OPTIONAL MATCH (tool)<-[:EXPLAINS_TOOL]-(book3:Book)

OPTIONAL MATCH (tool)<-[:PROVIDES_THEORY_FOR]-(book4:Book)

WITH tool,

collect(DISTINCT book.name) + collect(DISTINCT book2.name) +

collect(DISTINCT book3.name) + collect(DISTINCT book4.name) as books

RETURN books

Query 8: Get Related Case Studies

MATCH (cs:CaseStudy)

OPTIONAL MATCH (cs)-[r]-(tool:InnovationTool {name: '[TOOL_NAME]'})

RETURN cs.name, cs.description, cs.industry, cs.company,

cs.outcome, cs.lessons, cs.context, cs.frameworks_illustrated,

cs.teaching_notes, cs.discussion_questions, type(r) as relationship

Query 9: Get Examples

MATCH (ex:Example)

WHERE toLower(ex.name) CONTAINS toLower('[TOOL_NAME]')

Query 9: Get Examples

MATCH (ex:Example)

WHERE toLower(ex.name) CONTAINS toLower('[TOOL_NAME]')

OR toLower(ex.description) CONTAINS toLower('[TOOL_NAME]')

RETURN ex.name, ex.description, ex.context, ex.outcome

Query 10: Get Related Frameworks and Their Books

MATCH (tool:InnovationTool {name: '[TOOL_NAME]'})-[:RELATES_TO|PART_OF|USES]-(f:Framework)

OPTIONAL MATCH (f)<-[:ENHANCES_TOOL]-(book:Book)

RETURN f.name as framework, collect(DISTINCT book.name) as related_books

Query 11: Get Chunks with Tool Application Examples

MATCH (c:Chunk)

WHERE toLower(c.content) CONTAINS toLower('[TOOL_NAME]')

AND (toLower(c.content) CONTAINS 'example'

OR toLower(c.content) CONTAINS 'case'

OR toLower(c.content) CONTAINS 'application'

OR toLower(c.content) CONTAINS 'company'

OR toLower(c.content) CONTAINS 'organization')

RETURN c.name, c.content

LIMIT 20

Query 12: Get Historical Examples and Key Figures

MATCH (p:Person)-[r]-(tool:InnovationTool {name: '[TOOL_NAME]'})

RETURN p.name, p.role, p.contribution, type(r) as relationship

SYSTEM IDENTITY

You are an expert pedagogy architect specializing in the Problems Worth Solving (PWS) innovation methodology developed by Lawrence Aronhime at Johns Hopkins University. Your task is to generate complete educational materials for innovation tools in the Aronhime teaching style.

## FINAL PEER DEFENSE SESSION

### Instructions

This is not a review—it's a defense. Your peer will challenge your work, and you must defend it.

**Time Required:** 45-60 minutes

### Defense Protocol

**Part 1: Presentation (10-15 minutes)**

Present your complete findings without interruption.

**Part 2: Challenges (20-30 minutes)**

Peer asks probing questions. You defend your methodology and conclusions.

**Part 3: Feedback (10-15 minutes)**

Peer provides structured feedback.

### Defense Evaluation

| Element | Strong | Adequate | Weak |

|---------|--------|----------|------|

| Clarity of presentation | ☐ | ☐ | ☐ |

| Quality of evidence | ☐ | ☐ | ☐ |

| Rigor of methodology | ☐ | ☐ | ☐ |

| Ability to defend choices | ☐ | ☐ | ☐ |

### Problem: Outputs are superficial

**Symptoms:** Generic answers, completed too quickly

### Problem: Peer review is too gentle

**Symptoms:** All checkpoints pass, but quality is low

**Solution:** Model critical feedback. Review one participant's work publicly with rigorous standards.

---

### Problem: Participants can't connect to their context

**Symptoms:** "This doesn't apply to my industry"

### Problem: Participants resist the methodology

**Symptoms:** Shortcuts, complaints, "we already know this"

**Solution:** Return to Case Study 2 (the cautionary tale). Ask: "How would they have answered that objection?"

### Problem: Outputs are superficial

**Symptoms:** Generic answers, completed too quickly

**Solution:** Push for specificity using the "So what?" test. For every statement, ask "So what does that mean specifically?"

---

### Problem: Peer review is too gentle

**Symptoms:** All checkpoints pass, but quality is low

**Solution:** Model critical feedback. Review one participant's work publicly with rigorous standards.

---

### Problem: Participants can't connect to their context

**Symptoms:** "This doesn't apply to my industry"

JOBS TO BE DONE

Understanding the Progress People Seek

A Framework for Finding Problems Worth Solving

By Lawrence Aronhime

Johns Hopkins University

Problems Worth Solving • Week 3 • Ill-Defined Problems

Opening Provocation

Here's a question that will change how you see every product, every service, and every purchase you make:

"What job is your customer hiring your product to do?"

Stop and think about that. Not what features does your product have. Not what category does it compete in. Not what demographics buy it.

What job is it being hired to do?

The answer isn't 'to have a better drill'—that's describing the product, not the job. The answer isn't 'to be more efficient'—that's too vague to be useful.

The answer is: to make a quarter-inch hole. And once you understand that, you realize the drill doesn't compete with other drills. It competes with anything else that could make that hole. Lasers. Punches. Pre-made holes. Adhesive strips that eliminate the need for holes entirely.

Most innovators miss this. They obsess over making better drills. They add features. They study drill demographics. And they're blindsided when something completely different—something that does the same job better—destroys their market.

This is Jobs To Be Done—a framework that shifts your entire perspective from products to progress, from features to outcomes, from what you sell to what customers are actually trying to accomplish in their lives.

The Problem with Conventional Customer Understanding

Let me tell you why most customer research fails:

Consider a major fast-food chain trying to increase milkshake sales. They did everything the textbooks told them. They surveyed customers. They segmented by demographics—age, income, geography. They ran focus groups. They asked customers what would make the milkshake better. Customers dutifully answered: thicker, thinner, more chocolate, less chocolate, bigger cup, smaller price.

The company implemented the changes. Sales didn't move.

Why? Because they were asking the wrong questions. They were asking about the product instead of the job the product was being hired to do.

The Milkshake Revelation

Then a researcher took a different approach. Instead of asking about the milkshake, he watched customers. He noted when they bought milkshakes. At what time. What they were wearing. Whether they were alone. What else they bought—or didn't buy.

He discovered something remarkable: nearly half of all milkshakes were sold before 8:30 AM. To people in business attire. Alone. Who got in their cars and drove away.

The researcher started interviewing these morning customers. Not about the milkshake—about their lives. And he discovered the job:
title: Jobs To Be Done Lecture

content:
ple in business attire. Alone. Who got in their cars and drove away.

The researcher started interviewing these morning customers. Not about the milkshake—about their lives. And he discovered the job:

"I have a long, boring commute. I need something to keep me occupied. I need something I can consume with one hand while I drive. I need something that won't make a mess on my clothes. And I need it to last—I don't want to be hungry at 10 AM."

The milkshake wasn't competing with other milkshakes. It was competing with bagels (too messy, too fast), bananas (gone in three bites), donuts (guilt-inducing, crumbs everywhere), and coffee (not filling enough).

The milkshake was being hired for the job of 'Give me something engaging, clean, and filling for my boring commute.'

That's a completely different design brief than 'make the milkshake taste better.' And it leads to completely different innovations—a thicker consistency (lasts longer), a narrower straw (takes more effort, lasts longer), fruit chunks (surprise moments), a commuter-friendly cup shape.

Why Demographics Fail

The demographic approach—'18-34 year old males in suburban areas'—tells you nothing about why someone buys. Two people with identical demographics might hire the same product for completely different jobs:

A morning commuter hiring the milkshake for engagement and satiation

An afternoon parent hiring the same milkshake to be a 'good dad' (giving a treat to a demanding child)

Same product. Same demographic. Different job. Different design implications.

The morning job wants thick, slow, filling. The afternoon job wants fast (kid needs to finish before they get home), small (minimal sugar guilt), interactive (fun for the child).

Demographics describe who. Jobs describe why.

Where This Thinking Comes From

Clayton Christensen and the Theory of Jobs

The Jobs To Be Done framework was developed primarily by Clayton Christensen, the Harvard Business School professor best known for 'The Innovator's Dilemma.' But where that work focused on why good companies fail, JTBD focuses on why products succeed.

Christensen's insight came from asking a deceptively simple question: 'What causes a customer to purchase a product?' His answer revolutionized how we think about markets:

"Customers don't buy products. They hire them to make progress in their lives."

This wasn't just semantic wordplay. It was a fundamental reframe. Products are tools for achieving outcomes. Understanding the outcome—the progress the customer seeks—reveals what truly drives purchase decisions.

The Origins: Theodore Levitt and Marketing Myopia

The Origins: Theodore Levitt and Marketing Myopia

The intellectual roots go back further, to Theodore Levitt's 1960 Harvard Business Review article 'Marketing Myopia.' Levitt argued that companies failed when they defined themselves by the products they made rather than the customer needs they served.

His famous example: railroads declined not because people stopped needing transportation, but because railroads thought they were in the 'railroad business' instead of the 'transportation business.' They let cars, trucks, and planes take their customers.

"People don't want a quarter-inch drill. They want a quarter-inch hole."

Levitt identified the problem. Christensen developed the systematic framework for solving it.

Contributing Thinkers

The framework has been enriched by numerous contributors:

Tony Ulwick developed Outcome-Driven Innovation, a systematic method for identifying the outcomes customers seek when 'hiring' products

Bob Moesta, who worked with Christensen on the original milkshake study, developed practical interview techniques for uncovering jobs

Alan Klement contributed to understanding the emotional and social dimensions of jobs, not just functional ones

Together, they've created a robust methodology for understanding what progress people seek and why current solutions fall short.

The Jobs To Be Done Framework

What We Mean by 'Job'

A job is the progress that a person is trying to make in a particular circumstance.

Let's unpack each element:

Progress: Movement toward a better state. Customers aren't satisfied with where they are; they're trying to get somewhere better.

Person: Real human beings with complex lives, not abstract market segments or demographic categories.

Circumstance: The specific situation that creates the need. Context is everything—the same person may have different jobs in different situations.

A job is NOT:

A product category ('I need a car')

A feature ('I need Bluetooth')

A task ('I need to get to work')

A demographic need ('Millennials want...')

A job IS:

A statement of desired progress in context

Independent of any solution

Stable over time (even as solutions change)

The Three Dimensions of Every Job

Every job has three dimensions that must be understood together:

1. Functional Dimension

The practical, objective requirements. What does the person need to accomplish? This is the 'get it done' aspect:

'Get to work on time'

'Keep food fresh'

'Communicate with colleagues'

2. Emotional Dimension

How does the person want to feel—or avoid feeling? This is the internal, psychological aspect:

'Get to work on time'

'Keep food fresh'

'Communicate with colleagues'

2. Emotional Dimension

How does the person want to feel—or avoid feeling? This is the internal, psychological aspect:

'Feel in control of my commute'

'Feel confident I'm feeding my family well'

'Feel connected despite working remotely'

3. Social Dimension

How does the person want to be perceived by others? This is the external, relational aspect:

'Be seen as successful' (nice car)

'Be seen as a good parent' (healthy food)

'Be seen as a team player' (responsive communication)

Products that address only the functional dimension often lose to competitors who address emotional and social dimensions too. People will pay more—and be more loyal—to products that make them feel good and look good, not just get things done.

The Four Core Principles

Jobs are stable even as solutions change. People have needed to 'get entertainment while traveling' for centuries. The solutions have evolved from books to Walkmans to iPods to smartphones. The job remains constant.

Jobs exist independent of your product. The job exists whether your product exists or not. This is crucial—you don't create the job, you discover it.

Circumstances are critical. The same person has different jobs in different situations. Don't confuse the person with the circumstance.

Success is measured by customer progress, not product metrics. Features shipped, patents filed, technology advancement—none of these matter if the customer isn't making progress.

Why Jobs To Be Done Matters for Innovation

Reason 1: It Reveals Your True Competition

When you understand the job, you see competition you never knew existed.

The morning milkshake doesn't compete with other milkshakes—it competes with bagels, bananas, coffee, and podcasts (another way to make the commute less boring).

Netflix understood this. Reed Hastings famously said Netflix competes with sleep. The job isn't 'watch a movie.' The job is 'relax and unwind at the end of the day.' Sleep does that job too—and it's free.

Once you see your true competition, you can design for competitive advantage on dimensions that matter.

What happens if you ignore this: You optimize against the wrong competitors and get blindsided when something outside your category does the job better.

Reason 2: It Identifies Underserved Needs

Jobs analysis reveals where customers are struggling—where they've hired a product but it's doing the job poorly.

Reason 2: It Identifies Underserved Needs

Jobs analysis reveals where customers are struggling—where they've hired a product but it's doing the job poorly.

These struggles manifest as workarounds. Customers duct-tape solutions together. They hire multiple products to do one job. They spend excessive time on tasks. They feel frustrated.

Every workaround is an innovation opportunity. Every struggle is a problem worth solving.

What happens if you ignore this: You keep adding features nobody asked for while customers continue to struggle with the basics.

Reason 3: It Creates Customer Language, Not Product Language

Jobs statements use customer language—the way people actually describe their lives and goals. This has profound implications for:

Marketing that resonates (because it describes the customer's world, not your product's features)

Sales conversations (that start with the customer's struggle, not your solution)

Product development (that prioritizes what matters to customers, not what's technically interesting)

What happens if you ignore this: Your marketing describes features nobody cares about, your sales force struggles to connect, and your engineers build technically impressive products that customers ignore.

Reason 4: It Enables Predictive Innovation

Jobs are stable. Solutions change. This means you can predict where innovation opportunities exist by identifying jobs that are important but poorly served.

Jobs are stable. Solutions change. This means you can predict where innovation opportunities exist by identifying jobs that are important but poorly served.

You don't need to guess what customers want. You analyze the gap between how important the job is and how well current solutions do it. Large gaps = large opportunities.

What happens if you ignore this: You're reduced to guessing, following trends, or copying competitors—none of which leads to sustainable differentiation.

The Jobs To Be Done Method: 6 Steps

Step 1: Choose Your Domain

Objective: Define where you're looking for jobs.

You can't find every job. You need boundaries. Your domain might be:

A customer segment ('enterprise CFOs')

A life domain ('personal finance management')

A product category you serve ('office furniture')

A process ('preparing for retirement')

The domain should be broad enough to find meaningful jobs but narrow enough to be researchable.

Output: A clear statement of the domain you're exploring.

Step 2: Conduct Jobs Interviews

Objective: Understand how people experience the domain through their eyes.

This is NOT a focus group about your product. It's an exploration of the customer's life.

Key interview approaches:

Timeline interviews: Walk through a recent purchase or decision chronologically. 'Take me back to when you first thought about...'

Key interview approaches:

Switching interviews: Focus on moments when someone changed solutions. What drove the switch? What were they hoping would be different?

Struggle interviews: Explore where people are frustrated, where they create workarounds, where they spend more time than they think they should.

What to listen for:

Moments of struggle ('I always have to...')

Workarounds ('What I do is...')

Emotional language ('It's so frustrating when...')

Comparison to alternatives ('I used to... but now...')

Output: Rich qualitative data about experiences, struggles, and desired outcomes.

Step 3: Identify the Jobs

Objective: Articulate the jobs customers are trying to do.

The job statement format:

"[Subject/Stakeholder] + [Action Verb] + [Desired Outcome] + [Context]"

Examples:

'Help me arrive at work feeling prepared and energized (during my long commute)'

'Help me impress dinner guests (when hosting at home)'

'Help me stay connected with my team (while working remotely)'

Notice these statements:

Focus on progress (the outcome), not products

Include the circumstance (context matters)

Capture emotional dimensions ('feeling prepared', 'impress')

Are stable over time (won't change with technology)

Output: A set of clearly articulated job statements.

Step 4: Map Importance and Satisfaction

Objective: Prioritize jobs by opportunity size.

For each job, assess two dimensions:

Importance: How much does this job matter to customers? (Rate 1-10)

Satisfaction: How well do current solutions do this job? (Rate 1-10)

The opportunity calculation:

Opportunity = Importance + (Importance - Satisfaction)

This formula (from Tony Ulwick's ODI methodology) weights both the importance of the job and the gap between importance and current satisfaction.

High opportunity = High importance + Low satisfaction.

Output: A prioritized list of jobs based on opportunity size.

Step 5: Analyze the Job Ecosystem

Objective: Understand the full context of the job.

For your prioritized jobs, map:

What triggers the job? (What situation makes someone 'hire' a solution?)

What are the functional, emotional, and social dimensions?

What current solutions are hired? (Including non-obvious alternatives)

What workarounds exist?

What would 'perfect' look like? (The ideal outcome)

What prevents progress? (Obstacles and friction)

Output: Deep understanding of job context and customer struggles.

Case Studies: Jobs To Be Done in Action

Case Study 1: Intercom's Pivot

The Challenge: Intercom started as a simple customer messaging tool. They were growing, but leadership sensed they were missing the bigger opportunity.

Jobs Analysis: They conducted extensive customer interviews, not about the product, but about the customer's work. They discovered their customers weren't trying to 'send messages to customers.' They were trying to:

'Acquire new customers' (using chat for sales)

'Onboard and engage users' (using messages for activation)

'Support customers at scale' (using chat for support)

These were three different jobs, with different success metrics and different competitive sets.

The Insight: One product was being hired for three fundamentally different jobs. Intercom reorganized their entire product and company around these three jobs—creating distinct products and teams for each.

Impact: This clarity drove product decisions, marketing messaging, and organizational structure. Revenue grew from $30M to $200M in four years.

Key Lesson: The same product can be hired for multiple jobs. Understanding those jobs lets you serve each one better—or choose which to focus on.

Case Study 2: Snickers 'You're Not You When You're Hungry'

The Challenge: Snickers was just another candy bar in a crowded category. Share was stagnant.

Jobs Analysis: Traditional research said people ate Snickers for 'a chocolate treat.' But deeper investigation revealed a different job: 'Help me get back to being myself when I'm feeling off.'

The circumstance: That mid-afternoon slump when you're hungry and becoming someone you're not—irritable, unfocused, unpleasant to be around. The job wasn't 'eat chocolate.' It was 'restore myself to my normal, capable self.'

The Insight: This job revealed competition wasn't other candy bars—it was anything that could restore your true self: coffee, energy drinks, a quick walk, even just a break.

Impact: The 'You're Not You When You're Hungry' campaign directly addressed the job. It didn't talk about chocolate, nuts, or caramel. It talked about the transformation—from diminished to restored. Global sales increased by 15.9%.

Case Study 3: IKEA and the Job of Furnishing

The Challenge: Furniture was sold the same way for decades—showrooms full of individual pieces, sold by salespeople on commission.

Jobs Analysis: IKEA's founder, Ingvar Kamprad, understood a job that nobody else was addressing: 'Help me furnish my home affordably, starting now.'

The traditional furniture job statement: 'Help me buy quality furniture pieces for my home.' This led to expensive showrooms, commission sales, and 8-week delivery times.

IKEA's job statement: 'Help me create a home I'm proud of, on a budget, without having to wait.' This led to completely different design choices:

Flat-pack assembly (lower costs, immediate availability)

Room displays (inspiration, not just products)

In-store warehouse (take it home today)

Swedish food (make the shopping trip an experience)

Impact: IKEA became the world's largest furniture retailer by serving a job competitors weren't addressing.

Key Lesson: The right job statement leads to a coherent system of design choices. Everything at IKEA—from flat-pack to meatballs—flows from understanding the job.

Advanced Concepts

Hiring and Firing

Customers don't just hire products—they fire the old solution when they hire the new one. Understanding what gets fired reveals the real job.

Questions to ask:

'What were you using before?'

'What made you switch?'

'What did the old solution fail to do?'

'What do you miss about the old solution?'

The firing decision often reveals the job more clearly than the hiring decision.

The Four Forces

Every hiring/firing decision is driven by four forces:

Push: What's pushing the customer away from their current solution? (Dissatisfaction, problems)

Pull: What's pulling them toward a new solution? (Promise, appeal)

Anxiety: What concerns do they have about the new solution? (Risk, uncertainty)

Habit: What keeps them attached to the current solution? (Comfort, familiarity)

For a switch to happen: Push + Pull > Anxiety + Habit

Innovation often fails because it focuses only on Pull (making the new thing attractive) without reducing Anxiety or overcoming Habit.

Jobs Hierarchy

Jobs exist at different levels of abstraction:

Big Jobs: Life-level aspirations ('Be financially secure')

Little Jobs: Task-level needs ('Pay this bill')

Related Jobs: Jobs that cluster together ('Track my spending', 'Budget for the future')

Understanding the hierarchy helps you see where your solution fits in the customer's broader life context.

Non-Consumption

Sometimes the competition isn't an existing solution—it's nothing at all. Non-consumption is when customers don't hire anything to do the job because nothing adequate exists.

Non-consumption represents huge opportunity. These customers aren't comparing you to competitors—they're comparing you to the status quo of struggle.

Signs of non-consumption:

People doing things manually that could be automated

People avoiding activities because they're too hard

People accepting poor outcomes because they don't know better is possible

Jobs To Be Done + User Process Mapping

Process mapping reveals every step a user takes to accomplish a goal. Jobs To Be Done tells you what progress they're trying to make.

Together: Map the process, then for each step, ask: 'What job is being done here?' This reveals which steps are struggle points—where the job isn't getting done well.

Jobs To Be Done + Macro-Changes

Macro-changes (PEST analysis) show what's changing in the world. Jobs To Be Done reveals how those changes create new jobs or change how old jobs get done.

Together: For each macro-change, ask: 'What jobs does this create?' 'What jobs does this make obsolete?' 'What jobs does this make easier or harder?'

Jobs To Be Done is closely aligned with Gibson's 'Understanding Needs' lens—one of the four lenses of innovation.

Together: Use JTBD as the primary methodology for the Understanding Needs lens, then apply the other three lenses (Harnessing Trends, Challenging Orthodoxies, Leveraging Resources) to the jobs you discover.

Jobs To Be Done + Scenario Analysis

Scenario analysis explores alternative futures. Jobs analysis ensures you're thinking about those futures in terms of customer progress.

Together: For each scenario, ask: 'What jobs exist in this future?' 'Which jobs become more important?' 'Which current solutions become inadequate?'

Where Jobs To Be Done Fits in the PWS Methodology

Jobs To Be Done is a Week 3 tool in the Problems Worth Solving curriculum, positioned in the 'Ill-Defined Problems' phase.

Why Week 3?

By Week 3, you've explored the broad landscape of undefined problems—you've thought about macro-changes, scenarios, and systems. Now you need to get specific. Jobs To Be Done grounds abstract opportunities in concrete customer needs.

Why Ill-Defined Problems?

Jobs represent clear needs (there's a job to be done) but ambiguous solutions (many ways to do the job). This is the definition of an ill-defined problem.

The job is defined. The solution is not. This is exactly the right problem space for innovation.

Prerequisites

Before Jobs To Be Done analysis, you should have:

Understanding of your domain boundaries

Awareness of macro-changes affecting the space

Ability to conduct qualitative research

What Comes Next

After identifying jobs, the typical next steps are:

Four Lenses analysis to generate solution directions

White Space Mapping to find unserved market opportunities

Problem refinement to move toward well-defined problems

Common Mistakes in Jobs To Be Done

Mistake 1: Describing Solutions, Not Jobs

The Problem: 'Customers need a faster car' is not a job statement—it's a solution statement disguised as a need.

The Reality Check: Job statements should be solution-agnostic. Test by asking: 'Could this job be done by something completely different?'

The Reality Check: Job statements should be solution-agnostic. Test by asking: 'Could this job be done by something completely different?'

The Fix: Reframe as progress: 'Help me get to my destination quickly and comfortably.' Now you can imagine solutions beyond cars—telecommuting, moving closer, better public transit, autonomous vehicles.

Mistake 2: Ignoring Context

The Problem: 'Help me be entertained' is too broad. Without context, you can't design for the job.

The Reality Check: The same person has different entertainment jobs in different contexts—commuting, waiting at the doctor, relaxing at home.

The Fix: Always include circumstance: 'Help me be entertained while waiting in a boring situation (where I can't make noise).' Now you can design for it—earbuds required, short-form content, interruptible.

Mistake 3: Asking Customers What They Want

The Problem: 'What features would you like in a milkshake?' gets you incremental answers about milkshake features, not job insights.

The Reality Check: Customers don't know what they want. They know what they're struggling with.

The Fix: Ask about struggles, not solutions. 'Tell me about your morning commute.' 'What's frustrating about it?' 'What do you wish were different?' Let the job emerge from the struggle story.

Mistake 4: Missing Emotional and Social Dimensions

Mistake 4: Missing Emotional and Social Dimensions

The Problem: Focusing only on functional jobs—what customers need to accomplish—misses why products actually win.

The Reality Check: People often pay premium prices for emotional and social benefits, not functional superiority.

The Fix: For every functional job, ask: 'How does the customer want to feel while doing this?' 'How do they want to be perceived?' The Snickers case shows emotional jobs can be more powerful than functional ones.

Mistake 5: One Interview, One Job

The Problem: Conducting a handful of interviews and declaring 'we found the job.'

The Reality Check: Jobs emerge from patterns across multiple conversations. One interview might reveal a unique situation, not a generalizable job.

The Fix: Interview until you hear the same stories repeatedly. When interviewees start telling you things you've already heard, you've found the real jobs.

Mistake 6: Confusing the Job with the Moment

The Problem: 'I need to check my email' seems like a job, but it's actually a task within a larger job.

The Reality Check: Ask 'why' to find the real job. Why check email? To stay informed. Why stay informed? To be responsive. Why be responsive? To be seen as reliable and capable.

Mistake 7: Treating All Jobs as Equal

The Problem: Identifying ten jobs and giving them all equal weight in your product roadmap.

The Reality Check: Some jobs matter more than others. Some are better served by current solutions than others.

The Fix: Always map importance and satisfaction. Focus on jobs that are highly important but poorly served. These are your true opportunities.

The Ultimate Jobs To Be Done Question

After everything we've covered, here's the question that should guide your innovation efforts:

"What progress are people trying to make in their lives that they cannot currently make—or cannot make well?"

This question contains everything:

Progress: Not products, not features—forward movement in someone's life

People: Real humans with complex lives, not abstract market segments

Trying: Active struggle, not passive acceptance

Cannot currently make: The gap between aspiration and reality

Or cannot make well: The struggle with inadequate current solutions

Great innovators see the world through this lens. They don't ask 'What can we build?' They ask 'What progress is blocked?'

Final Thought

Every purchase is a hiring decision. Every product is an applicant for a job. Your job is to understand the job.

The most successful products in history didn't win by being better products. They won by doing the job better:

The iPhone did the job of 'be connected and productive anywhere' better than separate phones, cameras, and computers

Uber did the job of 'get where I'm going safely and without hassle' better than traditional taxis

Airbnb did the job of 'feel at home while traveling' better than hotels

None of these was the obvious next product in their category. They were better ways to do the job.

When you truly understand the job—functional, emotional, and social—you see possibilities that competitors fixated on products will never see.

This is not just a framework. It's a fundamental reorientation from product-thinking to progress-thinking. Master it, and you'll never see markets the same way again.

"The job is what the customer hires the product to do. Understand the job, and you understand everything."

— Lawrence Aronhime

Map All Three Dimensions: For each job, identify the functional, emotional, and social dimensions.

Assess Importance and Satisfaction: Rate each job on importance (1-10) and current satisfaction (1-10). Calculate opportunity scores.

Identify Your Top Opportunity: Which job represents the biggest opportunity? Why?

Challenge Your Findings: Apply the three-question test—Is it real? What must be true? Can existing solutions address?

The job statement (properly formatted)

Evidence from interviews

Functional, emotional, and social dimensions

A Systematic Guide to Understanding Customer Progress

How to Use This Workbook

What You're Holding

This is not a textbook about Jobs To Be Done theory. This is a systematic methodology for discovering the progress your customers are trying to make—and finding the opportunities where they're struggling to make that progress.

You will work through four phases, each building on the previous one. By the end, you will have:

A clearly defined domain for your jobs analysis

Documented interviews revealing customer struggles and aspirations

A set of validated job statements with all three dimensions

A prioritized opportunity map showing where to focus innovation efforts

Challenged and tested insights ready for solution development

Time Investment

Phase 1: Foundation & Domain Definition → 2-3 hours

Phase 2: Customer Interview & Discovery → 6-10 hours (including interviews)

Phase 3: Job Analysis & Prioritization → 3-4 hours

Phase 4: Validation & Synthesis → 2-3 hours

Total: 13-20 hours of focused work

Materials Needed

Access to 5-8 potential customers in your domain

Recording device or detailed note-taking capability

Quiet space for interview analysis

This workbook (print or digital)

Mindset Required

Curiosity over confirmation. You're not validating your product ideas—you're discovering what progress people seek.

Historical Context: Why Jobs To Be Done Works

Success Story: Intercom's Transformation

In 2011, Intercom was a simple customer messaging tool. They were growing, but leadership felt they were building features, not solving problems. Their turning point came when they stopped asking 'What features should we build?' and started asking 'What jobs are our customers hiring us to do?'
title: Jobs To Be Done Workbook

content:
they were building features, not solving problems. Their turning point came when they stopped asking 'What features should we build?' and started asking 'What jobs are our customers hiring us to do?'

Through extensive customer research, they discovered their single product was being hired for three distinct jobs: acquiring new customers (sales), onboarding users (marketing), and supporting customers (service). Same product, three different jobs, three different success metrics.

They reorganized their entire company around these jobs—creating distinct products, teams, and go-to-market strategies for each. Revenue grew from $30M to $200M in four years. The insight wasn't a new feature—it was a new understanding of the jobs.

Cautionary Tale: Kodak's Product Myopia

Kodak invented the digital camera in 1975. They had the technology, the brand, and the market position. Yet they filed for bankruptcy in 2012.

What happened? Kodak thought they were in the 'film business.' They optimized for film sales, film development, and film-related products. They saw digital as a threat to film.

But customers didn't have a job called 'use film.' They had jobs like 'capture memories,' 'share moments with family,' and 'document my life.' Those jobs didn't require film. They required whatever did the job best.
title: Jobs To Be Done Workbook

content:
idn't have a job called 'use film.' They had jobs like 'capture memories,' 'share moments with family,' and 'document my life.' Those jobs didn't require film. They required whatever did the job best.

When smartphones made 'capture and share moments' easier than ever, Kodak's film-centric worldview left them unable to respond. They were optimizing the wrong product for a job that was being done better elsewhere.

The lesson: Understand the job, or watch someone else do it better.

📝 WORKSHEET 0.1: Your Opening Reflection

Before you begin your jobs analysis, answer these questions honestly:

1. Think of a product you use daily. What job does it do for you—not what features does it have, but what progress does it enable?

2. What would you 'fire' that product for? What would have to be true for you to switch to something completely different?

3. When you think about your innovation domain, what do you think customers want? Now ask yourself: is that a feature or a progress statement?

STEP 1.3: Interview Guide Preparation

Your interview should follow these sections. Customize for your domain:

'Tell me about [activity in your domain]. Walk me through a typical day/week when you're doing this.'

Timeline Questions (Understand Journey)

'Think back to the last time you [activity]. Take me through exactly what happened, step by step.'

'When did you first realize you needed to [activity]? What was happening in your life?'

Switching Questions (Understand Decisions)

'Have you ever changed how you do this? What made you switch?'

'What were you using before? What wasn't working?'

Struggle Questions (Find Opportunities)

'What's the most frustrating part of [activity]?'

'If you could wave a magic wand, what would be different?'

'What workarounds have you created?'

Emotional/Social Probes

'How did that make you feel?'

'What did others think about your choice?'

'What would it mean to you if this was better?'

Instructor's Guide to Teaching S-Curve Analysis

Problems Worth Solving Methodology

WHAT'S IN THIS PACKAGE

This materials package contains four documents:

Total Package: Approximately 48,000 words of comprehensive S-Curve Analysis education

HOW TO USE EACH DOCUMENT

The Lecture

What it is: A complete teaching script covering the theory, methodology, and application of S-Curve Analysis—from the opening provocation (Kodak's bankruptcy) through the five-step methodology, case studies, common mistakes, and integration with other PWS tools.

How to use it:

As a complete lecture (2.5-3 hours): Deliver sections in order, pausing for discussion at case studies

As modular content: Each section can stand alone for targeted teaching

As reading assignment: Assign before workshop to establish foundation

Teaching recommendations:

The opening provocation sets the emotional tone—don't rush it. Let students sit with the discomfort of the Kodak example.

The Intel vs. Kodak case study pair (one success, one failure) should be discussed as mirror images of the same analytical framework.

The "Five Steps" section is the operational core. Ensure students can articulate each step before moving to advanced concepts.

The Common Mistakes section works well as small-group discussion: "Which of these have you seen? Which are you most likely to commit?"

Validation criteria distinguish minimum requirements from excellence. Use the excellence indicators to motivate high performers.

COMPARISON WITH RELATED CONCEPTS

Students often confuse S-Curve Analysis with related concepts. Clarify distinctions:

Common Confusion: S-Curve vs. Hype Cycle

The Gartner Hype Cycle is NOT an S-curve. It measures expectations and attention, not performance. A technology can be at the "trough of disillusionment" in the hype cycle while still climbing rapidly on its S-curve. The hype cycle describes perception; the S-curve describes reality.

Common Student Questions

"Doesn't AI make S-curves obsolete?" No. AI accelerates some curves, but every AI technology has its own S-curve. Neural network performance follows S-curves. Transformer architectures have limits. The tool applies to AI technologies just as it does to any other.

"What if I can't find any limits?" You haven't looked hard enough, or you've defined your domain too broadly. Every technology has limits. If you truly can't find limits, check if you're analyzing a product category instead of a technology.

"How far ahead can S-curves predict?" S-curve analysis is more reliable at identifying position and direction than predicting exact timing. Within-5-year predictions are reasonable; 10+ year predictions are directional only.

S-CURVE ANALYSIS: THE ART OF READING TECHNOLOGY'S FUTURE

A Lecture on Timing Innovation Investments Before Markets Force Your Hand

By Lawrence Aronhime

OPENING PROVOCATION

Here's a question that should keep every innovator awake at night:

Why did Kodak—a company that invented digital photography in 1975—go bankrupt in 2012?

The answer isn't "they didn't see digital coming." That's too simple. They saw it before anyone.

The answer isn't "they were arrogant." Every company in history has been arrogant at some point.

The answer is: They couldn't read the S-curve.

Kodak's leadership watched their film business reach physical and market limits for two decades. They saw the sigmoid shape forming in their revenue graphs. They even funded digital alternatives. But they fundamentally misread where they were on the curve—and more critically, they misjudged how much runway they had before the new curve would render their position obsolete.

This isn't ancient history. Right now, somewhere in your industry, a technology is reaching its limits. Right now, someone is placing bets on what comes next. The question is whether you can see it happening—and whether you know what to do about it.

Most organizations miss this entirely. They either:

Panic too early, abandoning profitable technologies before extracting full value

Stay too long, riding the curve into irrelevance while competitors leap to the next one

Panic too early, abandoning profitable technologies before extracting full value

Stay too long, riding the curve into irrelevance while competitors leap to the next one

Ignore it completely, treating technological transitions as someone else's problem

This is S-Curve Analysis—the systematic methodology for mapping where technologies sit in their lifecycle, identifying when they're approaching limits, and positioning for the transitions that reshape industries.

THE PROBLEM WITH HOW WE THINK ABOUT TECHNOLOGY

Let me tell you why most technology strategy fails:

We think in straight lines.

When we see a technology improving—getting faster, cheaper, more efficient—we unconsciously assume that improvement will continue at the same rate indefinitely. We draw a line through recent data points and extend it into the future. Our spreadsheets reward this thinking. Our planning cycles depend on it.

But technology doesn't improve in straight lines. It improves in S-curves.

The Linear Trap

Consider the hard disk drive industry in the 1990s. Companies were achieving roughly 60% annual improvements in storage density. If you plotted this on a graph and extended the line, you'd predict continued dominance for decades. Investment analysts did exactly this. Storage executives planned based on exactly this.

source_file: S-CURVE ANALYSIS_ THE ART OF READING TECHNOLOGY_S FUTURE.docx

content:
ge density. If you plotted this on a graph and extended the line, you'd predict continued dominance for decades. Investment analysts did exactly this. Storage executives planned based on exactly this.

What they missed: the physical limit. Eventually, magnetic recording hits fundamental constraints—the superparamagnetic limit, where bits become so small they're thermally unstable. The industry was racing toward a wall they couldn't see in their linear projections.

Meanwhile, flash memory was crawling along its own S-curve—slower improvement, higher cost per gigabyte, but with dramatically different physical limits. Today, flash has displaced rotating storage in most applications. The companies that saw the S-curve transition captured the future. Those that didn't... didn't.

Why This Matters for Innovation

Here's the gap this creates:

Traditional planning assumes continuity. S-curves guarantee discontinuity.

Every technology has limits. Physical limits. Market limits. Adoption limits. When a technology approaches these limits, improvement doesn't stop—it exhausts itself. The curve flattens. Returns diminish. And the conditions ripen for something new.

The organizations that thrive in this environment aren't the ones with the best technology. They're the ones who can read where they are on the curve—and position for what comes next.

This is what S-Curve Analysis enables: the systematic identification of technology timing opportunities.

WHERE THIS THINKING COMES FROM

WHERE THIS THINKING COMES FROM

The Intellectual Foundation

The S-curve pattern wasn't discovered in business. It was discovered in biology.

In 1838, Pierre François Verhulst was studying population growth. He noticed that populations don't grow indefinitely—they follow a characteristic pattern. Initial growth is slow. Then it accelerates exponentially. Then, as resources become constrained, it slows. The population approaches a limit asymptotically—never quite reaching it, but getting progressively closer.

The mathematical model he developed produced a shape: the logistic curve. An S-curve.

What's remarkable is how universal this pattern proves to be. It shows up in epidemic spread, in species colonization of new habitats, in the diffusion of innovations through societies, in the improvement of technologies over time. Something about the S-curve captures a deep truth about how systems grow and mature under constraints.

The Key Thinkers

Richard Foster brought S-curve thinking to technology strategy with his 1986 book Innovation: The Attacker's Advantage. Foster, then a director at McKinsey, observed that established companies repeatedly lose to newcomers despite superior resources. His explanation: technological limits and the S-curve.

Foster articulated two critical insights:

McKinsey, observed that established companies repeatedly lose to newcomers despite superior resources. His explanation: technological limits and the S-curve.

Foster articulated two critical insights:

Every technology has a natural limit—a point beyond which additional effort yields diminishing returns

The danger zone is the top of the S-curve—where incumbents feel most comfortable, because performance is strong, but where they're most vulnerable, because the technology has exhausted its improvement potential

Clayton Christensen extended this thinking with his work on disruptive innovation. Christensen observed that disruption often comes from technologies that initially underperform the incumbent—but sit on a steeper S-curve. The disrupting technology starts weak but improves faster, eventually overtaking the established solution.

Everett Rogers contributed the demand-side perspective with Diffusion of Innovations. While Foster and Christensen focused on technology performance, Rogers mapped how technologies spread through populations. His adoption curve—moving from innovators to early adopters to early majority to late majority to laggards—is itself an S-curve, but measuring market penetration rather than technical performance.

Genrich Altshuller, the Soviet inventor who developed TRIZ (Theory of Inventive Problem Solving), applied S-curve analysis to predict innovation opportunities. Altshuller studied thousands of patents and found that technologies evolve through predictable stages—with each stage creating specific types of innovation opportunities.

From Origin Domain to Innovation

The power of S-curve analysis for innovation comes from a simple recognition: if you know where you are on the curve, you know what kinds of opportunities exist.

At the beginning of an S-curve:

The technology shows promise but underperforms established alternatives

Innovation opportunities focus on proving feasibility and finding initial applications

The right strategy is patient investment and learning

In the steep middle section:

The technology improves rapidly with each unit of effort

Innovation opportunities focus on capturing growing markets and establishing standards

The right strategy is aggressive scaling and market expansion

At the top of the S-curve:

The technology approaches physical or market limits

Innovation opportunities focus on finding the next S-curve before this one exhausts

The right strategy is disciplined extraction while investing in alternatives

Understanding origins matters because it reveals that S-curves are diagnostic tools, not just descriptive ones. The curve tells you where you are. And where you are determines what you should do.

THE S-CURVE ANALYSIS FRAMEWORK

What We Mean By S-Curve Analysis

S-Curve Analysis is a structured methodology for:

Mapping where a technology sits in its lifecycle

Identifying the physical and market limits that constrain improvement

Detecting signals that a technology is approaching those limits

Positioning for transitions to new technological paradigms

The tool answers the fundamental question of technology timing: When should you invest in the incumbent? When should you invest in the disruptor? And how do you know?

The Four Core Principles

Principle 1: Every Technology Has Limits

No technology improves forever. At some point, fundamental constraints—physical, economic, or social—stop improvement. Understanding these limits is the first step in reading the curve.

Example: Internal combustion engines have approached their theoretical thermodynamic efficiency limits. No amount of engineering will fundamentally change this. The industry is not experiencing temporary stagnation—it's experiencing physics.

Principle 2: Effort-Performance Relationships Follow Predictable Patterns

Early in a technology's development, improvement comes slowly despite significant effort—the "embryonic" phase. Then something clicks, and improvement accelerates dramatically—the "growth" phase. Finally, improvement slows again as limits approach—the "mature" phase.

Example: The first transistors required heroic efforts to produce. Then came decades of rapid scaling following Moore's Law. Now, further miniaturization faces quantum mechanical limits, and each generation requires exponentially more investment.

Principle 3: The Danger Zone Is Where You Feel Most Comfortable

At the top of an S-curve, financial performance often looks strongest. Market share is high. Profit margins may be optimized. This creates a paradox: the moment of greatest apparent strength is often the moment of greatest strategic vulnerability.

Example: Blockbuster was most profitable in 2004, just four years before bankruptcy. Its leadership celebrated efficiency gains while the streaming S-curve was steepening beneath their feet.

Principle 4: New S-Curves Initially Underperform

Principle 4: New S-Curves Initially Underperform

The technology that replaces you won't beat you on day one. It will initially look inferior by current metrics. The disruption comes from a steeper improvement trajectory and different performance dimensions that become more important over time.

Example: Early digital cameras took terrible photos. They also didn't need film, developing, or photo stores. The performance dimension that mattered changed.

Key Concepts and Terminology

Physical Limit: The fundamental constraint—often rooted in physics, chemistry, or biology—that caps a technology's improvement potential. Cannot be engineered around.

Market Limit: The demand-side constraint that caps a technology's improvement potential even when physical improvement remains possible. Occurs when performance exceeds customer needs.

Inflection Point: The transition from one phase of the S-curve to another. The shift from slow growth to rapid growth, or from rapid growth to maturity.

Technology Discontinuity: The jump from one S-curve to a fundamentally different one. Represents paradigm change rather than incremental improvement.

Overlapping S-Curves: The pattern where a new technology's curve begins rising while the incumbent's curve is flattening. The transition window where strategic choices matter most.

Performance Overshoot: When a technology exceeds what customers actually need, creating vulnerability to "good enough" alternatives that compete on other dimensions.

Why It Works: The Mechanism

S-Curve Analysis works because it converts abstract strategic questions into concrete diagnostic questions:

Instead of asking "Will this technology last?" ask "What physical limits constrain improvement?"

Instead of asking "Should we invest in alternatives?" ask "Where are we on the current S-curve, and what does that position imply?"

Instead of asking "Is the disruptor a threat?" ask "What is the slope of their curve relative to ours?"

The power is in the discipline—forcing rigorous analysis of timing and limits rather than optimistic extrapolation of current trends.

WHY S-CURVE ANALYSIS MATTERS FOR INNOVATION

Reason 1: It Prevents Presentism

Professor Aronhime warns constantly about presentism—the assumption that the future will be like the present. S-Curve Analysis is perhaps the most powerful antidote.

When you map where a technology sits on its curve, you can't hide from timing reality. The curve forces you to confront: this cannot continue indefinitely. Something will change. What will it be?

S-Curve Analysis would have shown: electronic word processing is on a steeper curve. The typing interface has reached its limits. The curve-jump is coming.

Without S-Curve Analysis: Leaders extrapolate current conditions.

Reason 2: It Identifies Investment Timing

Knowing where you are on an S-curve determines how you should allocate resources. Early-stage technologies need patient capital and room to fail. Mature technologies need harvesting strategies. Transitional periods need hedged bets.

Example: Shell Oil in the 1970s used S-curve thinking to recognize that easy oil was approaching limits. This drove their famous scenario planning work—and their early investments in alternatives. They didn't abandon oil; they positioned for what came after.

Without S-Curve Analysis: Resources flow to wherever margins are currently highest—which is often exactly where they shouldn't go.

Reason 3: It Reveals Innovation Opportunity Types

Different positions on the S-curve create different innovation opportunities:

Early curve: Opportunities in feasibility demonstration and initial application discovery

Most organizations react to S-curve transitions after they've happened. S-Curve Analysis enables proactive positioning—seeing the transition early enough to influence it rather than merely survive it.

Case Study 1: Intel and the Microprocessor Transition — A Proactive Success

The Challenge:

In the early 2000s, Intel dominated the microprocessor market with its Pentium architecture. Performance had improved according to Moore's Law for decades. But by 2004, Intel hit a wall. Clock speeds reached 4 GHz, and further increases created unsustainable heat. The single-core performance S-curve was flattening.

The Application:

Intel's leadership used S-curve thinking to diagnose the situation. Key questions:

The Application:

Where are we on the curve? Approaching the plateau—diminishing returns from traditional scaling.

What alternatives exist? Multi-core architectures offered a new S-curve—parallel processing rather than serial speed.

Intel made a strategic bet: abandon the race for higher clock speeds and transition to multi-core processors. This required:

Retraining their engineering organization around parallel architecture

Reeducating the market about performance metrics

Coordinating with software developers to leverage multiple cores

The Key Insight:

Intel recognized they were at the top of one S-curve and needed to jump to another before the market forced them. By making the transition proactively, they maintained leadership position despite the paradigm shift.

The Impact:

Intel maintained market dominance through the transition. Their multi-core chips (Core 2 Duo, then Core i-series) defined the next era of computing. Competitors who tried to extend the single-core curve (primarily AMD at that point) fell behind.

The Lesson:

Proactive S-curve transitions preserve market position. Intel didn't wait for multi-core to prove itself—they drove the transition based on reading the curves.

Case Study 2: Kodak — A Cautionary Tale

The Challenge:

Kodak dominated film photography for most of the 20th century. By the 1980s, digital imaging was emerging from Kodak's own labs. Leadership faced a classic S-curve question: how to respond to a technology that currently underperforms but shows a steeper improvement trajectory?

The Application (or Lack Thereof):

Kodak's leadership misread multiple aspects of the S-curve transition:

They misread their curve position: Film chemistry had room for incremental improvement, but the curve was clearly flattening. Kodak interpreted continued profits as continued health.

They underestimated the alternative curve slope: Digital imaging improved faster than they projected. By the time digital quality matched film for consumer purposes, Kodak was years behind competitors.

They failed to identify market limits: Consumers didn't need archival-quality images. "Good enough" digital plus instant preview plus easy sharing exceeded the market limit threshold long before digital matched film technically.

ADVANCED CONCEPTS AND MENTAL MODELS

Mental Model 1: The Sailing Ship Effect

When steamships first appeared, sailing ship builders didn't surrender—they improved. Sailing ships got faster, more efficient, more sophisticated. This "sailing ship effect" is a predictable response to S-curve transitions: the incumbent technology accelerates improvement as a competitive response to the emerging alternative.

Application: Don't confuse a final flourish of incumbent improvement with a new S-curve. The sailing ships got better—and then they disappeared entirely. Watch the slopes, not the latest data point.

Example: When streaming emerged, cable companies dramatically improved their offerings—on-demand, DVR, premium channels. This didn't change the fundamental S-curve dynamics. It merely created a final flourish before cord-cutting accelerated.

Mental Model 2: Performance Dimension Shifts

S-curve transitions often involve not just a new technology but a new definition of performance. The disrupting technology wins not by beating the incumbent on current metrics but by changing which metrics matter.

Example: Digital photography initially couldn't match film quality. But digital introduced new performance dimensions—instant preview, unlimited shots, easy sharing, no developing costs. These dimensions became more important than archival quality for most users.

Mental Model 3: Overlapping S-Curves and the Transition Window

S-curves don't switch instantaneously. There's a window where the incumbent curve is flattening while the alternative curve is steepening. This "transition window" is where strategic choices matter most—and where most organizations make their critical mistakes.

Application: Identify where you are in the transition window. Early in the window, the incumbent is still extractable. Late in the window, the die is cast. Mid-window is where proactive positioning pays off.

Example: The smartphone transition window lasted roughly from 2005 (when smartphone improvement curves steepened) to 2010 (when the transition was unmistakable). Companies that positioned mid-window (Apple) captured the future. Companies that waited until late-window (BlackBerry) couldn't recover.

Mental Model 4: The Curve Position Paradox

Financial performance and strategic position often point in opposite directions. Companies at the top of an S-curve frequently show strong financials—high market share, optimized operations, peak profitability. But this is exactly when they're most vulnerable to being displaced by alternatives.

Application: Never confuse current financial performance with strategic health. The two can diverge dramatically at S-curve transitions.

Example: Blockbuster was most profitable in 2004. MySpace was most trafficked in 2008. BlackBerry was most sold in 2011. In each case, strong current metrics masked declining strategic position.

MISTAKE 1: Using Time Instead of Effort as the X-Axis

The Problem: Plotting performance against time produces misleading curves. Technologies can sit dormant when investment is low and accelerate dramatically when investment increases.

The Problem: Plotting performance against time produces misleading curves. Technologies can sit dormant when investment is low and accelerate dramatically when investment increases.

The Reality Check: The true S-curve relationship is between effort (R&D spending, engineering hours, experimental iterations) and performance. Time is a confounding variable.

The Fix: Always try to gather investment or effort data alongside performance data. If time is all you have, be aware you're seeing a distorted picture.

Example: Artificial intelligence appeared to plateau from the 1980s to 2010s when plotted against time. But investment also plateaued. When deep learning investment surged, so did performance. The curve never changed—effort allocation did.

MISTAKE 2: Ignoring Market Limits

The Problem: Focusing exclusively on physical limits while ignoring market limits. A technology can become vulnerable long before it hits physical constraints.

The Reality Check: If performance exceeds what customers actually need, the technology is at market limit regardless of physical headroom.

The Fix: Always assess both physical limits (what's theoretically possible) and market limits (what customers actually value). The relevant limit is whichever comes first.

MISTAKE 3: Dismissing Alternatives That Currently Underperform

The Problem: Rejecting alternative technologies because they don't match incumbent performance today.

The Reality Check: The defining characteristic of disruptive S-curves is that they start underperforming. That's not a reason to dismiss them—it's a reason to watch them carefully.

The Fix: Evaluate alternatives based on their trajectory, not their current position. A steeper curve that starts lower will eventually cross a flatter curve that starts higher.

Example: Every major technology transition has followed this pattern. Early cars were slower than horses. Early digital cameras produced worse images than film. Early smartphones had worse voice quality than feature phones.

MISTAKE 4: Assuming Transitions Happen When Curves Cross

The Problem: Expecting S-curve transitions to occur precisely when the alternative achieves performance parity with the incumbent.

The Reality Check: Adoption barriers (infrastructure, regulation, learning curves, network effects) can delay transitions significantly beyond curve-crossing points.

The Fix: Analyze adoption barriers alongside performance curves. The transition happens when performance crosses AND adoption barriers are surmountable.

Example: Electric vehicle performance crossed gasoline vehicle viability years ago for many use cases. But charging infrastructure, purchase price, and range anxiety created adoption barriers that delayed mass transition.

MISTAKE 5: Extrapolating Linear Improvement

The Problem: Assuming that recent improvement rates will continue indefinitely. Drawing a straight line through recent data points.

The Reality Check: All S-curves flatten. Recent rapid improvement is evidence of being in the growth phase—which is followed by maturity and flattening.

The Fix: When you see rapid improvement, ask: What limits will eventually constrain this? How far are we from those limits? Don't extrapolate—diagnose position.

Example: The famous failure of semiconductor industry predictions. Analysts repeatedly extrapolated Moore's Law linearly, ignoring the physical limits of miniaturization that eventually slowed improvement.

MISTAKE 6: Confusing S-Curve Position with Strategic Prescription

The Problem: Treating S-curve position as automatically dictating strategy (e.g., "We're at the top of the curve, so we must invest in alternatives").

The Reality Check: S-curve position is diagnostic, not prescriptive. The right strategy depends on your resources, capabilities, risk tolerance, and competitive position—not just curve position.

The Fix: Use S-curve analysis to understand the situation, then apply strategic judgment. An incumbent at the top of the curve might harvest, might invest in alternatives, might acquire the alternative leader, or might exit the industry.

Example: IBM was at the top of the mainframe S-curve when PCs emerged. They could have harvested mainframes and exited. Instead, they entered PCs (successfully initially), proving that curve position doesn't dictate a single strategy.

The Problem: Confusing incumbent technology's competitive response with a new S-curve. When alternatives emerge, incumbents often accelerate improvement—but this doesn't change the fundamental dynamics.

The Reality Check: A final flourish of improvement doesn't create a new curve. Watch the underlying limits, not the latest performance uptick.

THE ULTIMATE S-CURVE QUESTION

There's one question that separates those who truly understand S-Curve Analysis from those who merely go through the motions:

"What is the next S-curve that will obsolete our current success?"

This question should be uncomfortable. It requires you to contemplate the end of what's working. It demands that you take seriously the possibility that your current strength is temporary. It insists that you look beyond the horizon of your planning cycle.

But this discomfort is the point. The companies that ask this question proactively—that deliberately search for the technologies and approaches that could displace them—are the ones that survive S-curve transitions.

Kodak didn't fail because no one asked about digital photography. They failed because asking the question didn't translate into action. The question has to haunt your strategy, your investment decisions, your organizational evolution.

Every technology you depend on today sits somewhere on an S-curve. Every advantage you hold rests on an improvement trajectory that will eventually flatten. The question isn't whether change is coming—it's whether you'll see it early enough to shape it rather than merely survive it.

This question should haunt your work in the best possible way.

FINAL THOUGHT

S-Curve Analysis is ultimately about intellectual honesty regarding time.

Every technology has a beginning, a middle, and an end. Every improvement trajectory flattens. Every dominant paradigm eventually yields to something else. S-Curve Analysis is simply a disciplined way of facing these facts rather than ignoring them.

The organizations that thrive across technology transitions aren't necessarily smarter or better-resourced. They're the ones willing to look honestly at where they are on the curve—and to act on what they see rather than what they wish were true.

HOW TO USE THIS WORKBOOK

What You're Holding

This is not a textbook to read passively. This is not a collection of tips and tricks.

This is a systematic methodology for understanding where technologies stand in their lifecycle, when they will hit their limits, and where the opportunities lie for those who can see the curves before others do.

You will work through four phases, each building on the previous one. By the end, you will have:

✓ A complete S-Curve map of your technology domain

Mindset Required

S-Curve Analysis demands that you think in trajectories, not snapshots. Most people see technologies as they are today. You must train yourself to see them as they are becoming—to trace the path from emergence through maturity to decline.

HISTORICAL CONTEXT: THE CASE FOR S-CURVE ANALYSIS

A Success Story: Intel's Calculated Leap

In the late 1990s, Intel faced a classic S-curve dilemma. Their x86 processor architecture had driven thirty years of growth, but the physics were becoming unforgiving. Clock speeds couldn't increase forever—power consumption grew exponentially, heat dissipation became impossible, and the performance gains per dollar were flattening.

hysics were becoming unforgiving. Clock speeds couldn't increase forever—power consumption grew exponentially, heat dissipation became impossible, and the performance gains per dollar were flattening.

Many inside Intel wanted to keep optimizing. The x86 was their fortress, their moat, their identity. But the company's technology forecasters mapped the S-curve and saw the inflection point approaching. The question wasn't whether the limit would come, but when.

Intel made a strategic choice: invest heavily in multi-core architectures before the old curve flatlined completely. They didn't wait until crisis forced the decision. They read the curve, saw the future, and jumped early enough to maintain leadership through the transition.

The result? Intel navigated a fundamental technology transition without losing market dominance. They were criticized by some for "abandoning" clock speed optimization too early—but those critics were looking at the present. Intel was reading the curve.

A Cautionary Tale: Kodak's Comfortable Blindness

You know this story, but you probably don't know it well enough.

Kodak didn't miss digital photography. They invented it. In 1975, Kodak engineer Steven Sasson created the first digital camera. Kodak held key patents. They had the technology, the resources, and a twenty-year head start.

What they missed was the S-curve.

In 1975, Kodak engineer Steven Sasson created the first digital camera. Kodak held key patents. They had the technology, the resources, and a twenty-year head start.

What they missed was the S-curve.

Kodak's leadership looked at digital in the 1990s and saw an inferior technology. Film resolution vastly exceeded digital sensors. Film cameras were cheaper. The workflow was established. By every metric that mattered to them, film was winning.

What they failed to see was curve position. Digital was at the bottom of its S-curve—the part where performance improves slowly and the technology looks weak. Film was at the top of its S-curve—where performance is excellent but improvement has essentially stopped.

The defining characteristic of S-curves is that the technology at the bottom of a new curve eventually surpasses the one at the top of an old curve. Not might. Will. The physics of improvement favor the newer technology.

Kodak saw a snapshot—digital is worse than film. They should have seen trajectories—digital is improving at 40% per year while film improves at 2%.

By the time the curves crossed, it was too late. In 2012, Kodak filed for bankruptcy.

The Lesson

The Intel story and the Kodak story share the same underlying dynamic: S-curves are predictable, but only to those willing to look. The companies that survive technology transitions are those that map the curves honestly, accept what the curves tell them, and act while they still have room to maneuver.

STEP 1.1: Define Your Technology Domain

What This Step Accomplishes

Before you can map an S-curve, you must define precisely what technology you're mapping. This sounds obvious, but it's where most S-curve analyses fail. "Smartphones" is not a technology—it's a product category containing dozens of technologies, each on its own curve. "Lithium-ion batteries" is a technology. "NAND flash memory" is a technology. "CMOS image sensors" is a technology.

The more precisely you define your technology domain, the more accurate your S-curve mapping will be.

Why This Matters

If you define your domain too broadly, you'll conflate multiple S-curves and miss the specific dynamics that matter. If you define it too narrowly, you'll miss how your technology fits into larger systems. The goal is to find the level of specificity where performance parameters are meaningful and measurable.

STEP 1.2: Identify Key Performance Parameters

What This Step Accomplishes

S-curves measure performance improvement over time. But "performance" means different things for different technologies and different users. CPU clock speed matters for some applications; power efficiency matters for others. You must identify which performance parameters are relevant to your strategic question.

Why This Matters

The choice of performance parameters determines what your S-curve reveals. Choosing the wrong parameters is like mapping the wrong territory—you'll have beautiful curves that tell you nothing useful. The best parameter choices are those that: (1) matter to users, (2) drive competitive advantage, and (3) have physical limits.

PHASE 2: LIMIT ANALYSIS

Introduction

In Phase 2, you will identify and analyze the limits constraining your technology. This is the critical phase that separates useful S-curve analysis from superficial trend-following.

Every technology faces limits. Physical limits derive from nature—you can't exceed the speed of light, you can't violate thermodynamics. Market limits derive from economics—what customers will pay, what's "good enough," what competing priorities exist. Competitive limits derive from industry dynamics—what others are achieving, what's patented, what's accessible.

Understanding limits is understanding fate. A technology approaching its physical limits has a predictable future: improvement will slow, then stop. A technology far from its limits has runway for continued advance. The strategic implications differ entirely.

Phase 2 Objectives

[ ] Identified market limits (good enough thresholds)

[ ] Identified competitive limits (what's achievable vs. what's reached)

[ ] Calculated limit impact on remaining runway

[ ] Prioritized which limits will bind first

STEP 2.1: Physical and Theoretical Limits

What This Step Accomplishes

Every technology is constrained by physics. There are fundamental limits—speed of light, thermodynamic efficiency, atomic structure—that cannot be exceeded regardless of ingenuity. There are also practical physical limits—heat dissipation, material strength, quantum effects—that constrain implementation even before theoretical limits.

Why This Matters

Physical limits are the only truly hard limits. Everything else is negotiable. When you know you're approaching physical limits, you know the curve is ending. When you're far from physical limits, there's room for continued advance.

STEP 2.2: Market Limits—"Good Enough" Thresholds

What This Step Accomplishes

Not all limits are physical. Market limits occur when further improvement ceases to matter to customers—when the technology becomes "good enough." Once good enough is reached, further improvement doesn't drive adoption or willingness to pay.

Why This Matters

Market limits often arrive before physical limits. A technology can be far from its theoretical maximum but effectively "mature" because further improvement doesn't matter to users. This is Clayton Christensen's insight about overshooting customer needs.

Mistake 1: Analyzing Too Broadly

What it looks like: Mapping "AI" or "renewable energy" instead of specific technologies

Why it happens: Fear of missing something; difficulty defining boundaries

How to fix it: Ask: "Can I get quantitative performance data for this?" If no, you're too broad.

Mistake 2: Using Product Curves for Technology Curves

What it looks like: Mapping iPhone market share instead of CMOS sensor performance

Why it happens: Product data is more available than component data

How to fix it: Dig deeper—what specific technology enables the product? Map that.

Mistake 3: Ignoring Market Limits

What it looks like: Predicting decades of improvement based only on physics

Why it happens: Engineers focus on what's technically possible

How to fix it: Ask: "What's 'good enough' for customers?" Market limits often bind before physical limits.

Mistake 4: Assuming Linear Improvement

What it looks like: Extrapolating current rates indefinitely

Why it happens: Rates feel stable in the moment

How to fix it: Plot historical rates. They almost always decelerate as limits approach.

Mistake 5: Dismissing Early-Stage Alternatives

What it looks like: "That technology is too weak/expensive to matter"

Why it happens: Current-state bias; comparing to your mature technology unfairly

How to fix it: Compare improvement rates, not current performance. The weak alternative improving at 40%/year beats the strong incumbent improving at 5%/year.
