EXAMPLES OF EXCELLENCE

Example 1: Intel's Multi-Core Transition Analysis

An exemplary S-curve analysis would have mapped:

Current position: Clock speed approaching practical thermal limits

Physical limits: Heat dissipation at high frequencies; power scaling

Market limits: Most applications don't need faster single-thread

Alternative: Multi-core architectures in emergence phase

Crossing analysis: Multi-core could provide better performance-per-watt within 5 years

Opportunity: Jump to multi-core before thermal limits force it

What makes this excellent:

Specific technology focus (CPU clock speed)

Multiple limit types considered

Alternative identified early

Action taken proactively

Example 2: Tesla's Battery Strategy Analysis

An exemplary S-curve analysis of electric vehicle batteries would map:

Current position: Li-ion in growth phase, improvement rate ~7% annually on energy density

Physical limits: Lithium-ion theoretical limits (400+ Wh/kg) still distant

Market limits: 300-mile range is "good enough" for most—approaching rapidly

Alternatives: Solid-state in emergence; sodium-ion as low-cost option

Crossing analysis: Solid-state could cross in 7-10 years if manufacturing scales

Opportunity: Ride current curve while investing in solid-state capabilities

CASE STUDY 1: Shell's Scenario Planning — Using S-Curves to See What Others Missed

This case establishes how S-curve thinking enabled one of the most famous strategic successes in business history

CASE STUDY 2: Kodak — The Company That Invented Its Own Disruptor and Died Anyway

This case shows what happens when S-curve analysis is ignored despite having all the data

Classification

THE SITUATION

In 1975, Kodak engineer Steven Sasson invented the digital camera. Kodak held key patents. The company had research capabilities, brand recognition, distribution networks, and customer relationships that any competitor would envy. By every conventional measure, Kodak was positioned to dominate digital photography.

Instead, Kodak filed for bankruptcy in 2012.

This isn't a story about missing a technological shift. Kodak SAW the shift coming. They CREATED the technology that would destroy them. The failure was in S-curve analysis—specifically, in how Kodak interpreted what the curves were telling them.

What made this situation particularly challenging:

Film was extremely profitable: Kodak's film business generated margins exceeding 60%. Digital would cannibalize this.

Digital was genuinely inferior: In 1990, digital resolution, color accuracy, and workflow were objectively worse than film.

Network effects favored film: Photo labs, retailers, and consumers were all invested in film-based systems.

The conventional approach would have been:

Why that would have failed:

This IS what Kodak did. And it did fail. The conventional approach looked at current performance (film wins) instead of trajectory (digital was improving 40%+ annually while film improved incrementally).

THE APPLICATION (What Kodak Should Have Done)

What S-Curve Analysis Would Have Revealed:

Step 1: Map Positions on Respective Curves

Film technology: Near the top of its S-curve. Silver halide chemistry was mature. Resolution improvements were marginal. Manufacturing efficiency was optimized.

Digital imaging: At the bottom of its S-curve. CCD/CMOS sensors were primitive. But improvement rates were exponential—following semiconductor scaling laws.

Step 2: Identify Limits

Film limits: Grain structure imposed theoretical resolution limits. Chemical processing couldn't get much faster. Manufacturing costs had limited reduction potential.

Digital limits: Semiconductor physics allowed enormous headroom. Storage costs following Moore's Law. Processing power following Moore's Law.

Step 3: Calculate Crossing

A rigorous analysis in 1990 would have shown:

Digital resolution improving ~40% annually

What Kodak Actually Did:

Kodak's executives looked at snapshots, not trajectories. In 1990, they saw:

Film: Excellent quality, low cost, universal infrastructure

Digital: Poor quality, high cost, no infrastructure

They concluded (reasonably, from a snapshot view) that digital wasn't a threat to their core market.

They ignored the improvement rates. They ignored that their own curve was flattening while digital's was climbing. They made the classic mistake: comparing current performance instead of comparing trajectories.

Quantified Results:

The Crossing Point:

Around 2003-2004, digital image quality became "good enough" for mainstream consumers. This was the crossing point that S-curve analysis would have identified a decade earlier.

By the time the curves crossed, Kodak had no viable strategic options. Their film business collapsed faster than they could build a digital business. The S-curve transition, once triggered, was swift and merciless.

This case shows proactive S-curve navigation at its best

THE SITUATION

For three decades, Intel had a simple formula: make chips faster by increasing clock speed. Each generation ran at higher megahertz (then gigahertz) than the previous. Engineers, software developers, and consumers all measured processor performance by clock speed.

By the late 1990s, Intel's technical leaders saw a problem: the clock speed S-curve was approaching physical limits. Power consumption increased roughly with the cube of frequency. Heat dissipation was becoming impossible. The Pentium 4 architecture, designed for clock speed, was hitting thermal walls.

The question wasn't whether the limit would come—the physics was clear. The question was what to do about it.

What made this situation particularly challenging:

Clock speed was Intel's brand: "Intel Inside" meant "faster megahertz." Abandoning clock speed felt like abandoning identity.

Software wasn't ready: Applications weren't written for multi-core. Jumping to multi-core meant software couldn't fully use the capability.

AMD was attacking: AMD's Athlon chips were competitive on clock speed. A strategic pivot during competitive battle is risky.

THE APPLICATION

Step 1: Map the S-Curve Position

Intel's engineers mapped clock speed trajectory rigorously:

Historical improvement: ~50% annually for two decades

Current position: 2-3 GHz

Projected position: 4+ GHz by 2005

Physical limit: Power density approaching 100W/cm² (unmanageable)

The S-curve position was clear: late maturity, approaching physical limits.

Step 2: Identify the Binding Limit

Step 2: Identify the Binding Limit

The binding limit wasn't transistor density—Moore's Law had runway. The binding limit was power density. Heat dissipation became the constraint.

Intel calculated that a 4 GHz Pentium 4 would generate ~150W in a small die area—requiring cooling systems impractical for consumer PCs.

Step 3: Scan Alternatives

Intel identified multi-core architecture as the next curve:

Distribute workload across multiple slower cores

Power scales linearly (not cubically) with cores

Total performance can increase while per-core frequency decreases

New S-curve with substantial runway

Step 4: Assess Timing

Intel's analysis showed:

Clock speed curve would flatten ~2004-2005

Multi-core could be ready 2005-2006

Gap was manageable if they started immediately

The Pivotal Decision:

In 2004, Intel announced it would NOT pursue 4 GHz Pentium 4. Instead, it would transition to multi-core architecture. This was widely criticized. Analysts questioned whether Intel was conceding defeat. AMD celebrated.

But Intel had done the S-curve analysis. They knew clock speed was hitting limits. Better to jump to a new curve with runway than ride the old curve into the wall.

SECTION 2: MINI-CASES

Brief examples (150-250 words each) for rapid illustration

MINI-CASE A: Vacuum Tubes to Transistors

Context: In 1955, vacuum tubes were the foundation of electronics. They were mature, reliable, and well-understood. Transistors were finicky, expensive, and limited in power handling.

S-Curve Dynamic: Vacuum tubes were at the top of their S-curve. Transistors were at the bottom of a new curve with enormous runway (semiconductor scaling laws).

Result: By 1965, transistors dominated. By 1975, vacuum tubes were relegated to niche applications. Companies that stayed with tubes (like RCA's TV division) lost to companies that rode the transistor curve (Texas Instruments, later Intel).

Key Lesson: A mature technology with excellent current performance will be overtaken by an emerging technology with higher improvement rate.

MINI-CASE B: Hard Drives vs. Solid State

Context: In 2005, hard disk drives offered 10-100x the storage per dollar compared to solid-state drives. HDD manufacturers dismissed SSD as a niche product for military and aerospace.

S-Curve Dynamic: HDDs were approaching mechanical limits (platter density, read/write head positioning). SSDs were in early growth phase, following semiconductor scaling.

MINI-CASE C: Sailing Ships After Steam

Context: When steamships emerged in the 1820s, sailing ships were highly optimized. Steam was expensive, unreliable, and required coal. Sailing ship owners invested MORE in optimization—faster hulls, better rigging—in response to steam's emergence.

S-Curve Dynamic: Sailing ships were at the top of their curve with no improvement runway. Steam was at the bottom with massive potential improvement.

Result: The greatest sailing ships were built AFTER steam arrived—the "Sailing Ship Effect." But by 1900, steam dominated. All that optimization of the old technology was wasted investment.

Key Lesson: Incumbent investment often accelerates at exactly the wrong moment—when the new curve makes the old investment obsolete.

Result: By 2020, LED dominated general lighting. Incandescent manufacturing ceased in most countries. The crossing took ~25 years but was predictable from improvement rates.

Key Lesson: Long-timeline S-curve crossings can be anticipated and prepared for—if you map the trajectories.

Situation: You're evaluating solid-state battery technology as an alternative to lithium-ion for electric vehicles. Data is limited because the technology is emerging.

Use academic publications as proxy for development progress

Use patent filings as proxy for commercial interest

Use pilot project announcements as proxy for approaching commercialization

Create low/medium/high scenarios for improvement rates rather than single estimates.

How did similar technology transitions unfold?

Li-ion emergence (1990s): 10-15 years from lab to mainstream

THE ORIGINS

Where S-Curve Thinking Came From

The S-curve (or sigmoid curve) appears throughout nature and human systems: bacterial growth, epidemic spread, skill acquisition, technology adoption. Mathematicians recognized the pattern centuries ago. But applying it to technology strategy was a 20th-century development.

The Key Figure: Everett Rogers

The Key Figure: Everett Rogers

In 1962, sociologist Everett Rogers published Diffusion of Innovations, codifying the S-curve of adoption. His work showed that new technologies spread through populations following a predictable pattern: innovators → early adopters → early majority → late majority → laggards. The cumulative adoption curve is an S.

The Business Application: Richard Foster

While Rogers described adoption, Richard Foster (McKinsey) in the 1980s applied S-curve thinking to technology PERFORMANCE. His insight: each technology has a performance trajectory that follows an S-shape, and that trajectory has limits. When limits approach, new technologies can overtake incumbents.

The Organizational Dimension: Clayton Christensen

Christensen's work in the 1990s explained why companies fail at S-curve transitions even when they see them coming. He showed that organizational dynamics—customer relationships, profit models, capabilities—trap incumbents on the old curve.

SECTION 6: FAILURE ANALYSIS ARCHIVE

FAILURE PATTERN 1: Snapshot Bias

The Pattern

Analyzing current performance rather than trajectories. "Technology A is better than Technology B today, therefore A will continue to win."

Real Example

Company/Situation: Kodak vs. Digital Photography

What Happened: Kodak compared digital camera quality (poor) to film quality (excellent) in 1995. Conclusion: digital isn't a threat.

Cost: Bankruptcy; loss of ~$30 billion in market value

Warning Signs

Comparing static performance metrics without improvement rates

Dismissing alternatives as "too weak" or "too expensive"

Confidence increasing as current performance improves

Prevention

Always calculate improvement RATES. Compare trajectories, not positions. Ask: "Where will each technology be in 5/10 years at current improvement rates?"

FAILURE PATTERN 2: Ignoring Market Limits

The Pattern

Analyzing only physical/technical limits while ignoring "good enough" thresholds.

FAILURE PATTERN 2: Ignoring Market Limits

The Pattern

Analyzing only physical/technical limits while ignoring "good enough" thresholds.

Real Example

Company/Situation: Intel's Itanium architecture

What Happened: Itanium offered theoretical performance advantages but was complex and expensive. x86 was "good enough" for most applications and improving rapidly.

Cost: ~$10 billion invested; product line eventually discontinued

Warning Signs

Engineering-dominated analysis without market input

Focus on theoretical advantages without assessing customer willingness to pay

Dismissing "good enough" alternatives

Prevention

Always identify market limits alongside physical limits. Ask: "What performance is good enough for each customer segment?"

FAILURE PATTERN 3: Sailing Ship Effect

The Pattern

Investing MORE in the old technology as new technology emerges, trying to extend the old curve.

Real Example

Company/Situation: HDD manufacturers vs. SSD

What Happened: When SSDs emerged, HDD makers invested heavily in new platter technologies, helium filling, and other innovations to extend HDD performance.

Cost: Billions invested in technologies that couldn't change the ultimate outcome

Warning Signs

Acceleration of R&D on mature technology

"Breakthrough" announcements that extend old curve marginally

Investment justified by "buying time"

FAILURE PATTERN 4: Single-Parameter Analysis

The Pattern

Analyzing only one performance dimension when multiple matter.

Real Example

Company/Situation: Digital camera resolution focus

What Happened: Early digital camera assessment focused only on resolution (where film won). Ignored convenience, sharing, storage—where digital had advantages.

Cost: Delayed recognition of digital's market-relevant advantages

Warning Signs

Analysis focuses on incumbent's key parameter

Alternative's different value proposition dismissed as "not what customers want"

Customers' changing needs not tracked

Prevention

Map S-curves on multiple parameters. Recognize that performance dimensions shift as technologies mature. Ask: "What will customers value when current parameters are good enough?"

FAILURE PATTERN 5: Assuming Linear Improvement

The Pattern

Extrapolating current improvement rates indefinitely without accounting for deceleration.

Real Example

Company/Situation: Intel clock speed projections

What Happened: 1990s projections assumed clock speed would continue doubling every 18 months indefinitely. Reality: hit thermal wall at ~3 GHz.

DOMINANT DESIGNS: Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change

A Lecture on Finding Opportunity in Industry Transformation

By Lawrence Aronhime

OPENING PROVOCATION

Here's a question that should make you deeply uncomfortable:

What if everything you believe about your industry—the products you make, the way you compete, the customers you serve—is about to become irrelevant?

Not gradually. Not in some distant future you can comfortably ignore. But within a timeframe that will catch you flat-footed if you're not paying attention.

The answer isn't "stay competitive"—that's too vague to be useful. It's not "innovate more"—that's what everyone says. And it's certainly not "watch the market"—everyone watches the market, yet most still get blindsided.

The answer is: Learn to recognize when a dominant design is falling apart.

A dominant design is the fundamental architecture—political, economic, social, or technological—that an entire industry has collectively adopted because it solves multiple problems simultaneously. It's the QWERTY keyboard. The internal combustion engine. The 30-year fixed-rate mortgage. The semester-based university calendar.

These aren't just products or practices. They're the invisible agreements that structure entire industries. They determine who wins, who loses, what's possible, and what's unthinkable. And here's what most people miss: they don't last forever.
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
ey're the invisible agreements that structure entire industries. They determine who wins, who loses, what's possible, and what's unthinkable. And here's what most people miss: they don't last forever.

Every dominant design carries within it the seeds of its own obsolescence. The very features that made it successful create blind spots. The very efficiencies it enables create rigidities. The very problems it solves make practitioners forget that other problems exist.

This is Dominant Designs Analysis—the systematic practice of identifying when the rules of competition are about to change, and positioning yourself to benefit from the transformation rather than be destroyed by it.

Most innovators miss this. They focus on improving existing products within the current rules. They compete harder at the game everyone else is playing. They're like chess masters perfecting their strategy while the world is shifting to a different game entirely.

The opportunity isn't in playing the current game better. The opportunity is in recognizing when the game itself is changing.

THE PROBLEM WITH CONVENTIONAL COMPETITIVE ANALYSIS

Let me tell you why most competitive strategy fails spectacularly at the moments that matter most.

Consider a typical strategic planning session. The team gathers. They analyze competitors. They benchmark best practices. They identify market trends. They create elaborate spreadsheets projecting market share, pricing scenarios, and growth trajectories.
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
m gathers. They analyze competitors. They benchmark best practices. They identify market trends. They create elaborate spreadsheets projecting market share, pricing scenarios, and growth trajectories.

And almost all of this analysis assumes one crucial thing: that the fundamental structure of the industry will remain stable.

The spreadsheets assume customers will continue wanting roughly the same things. The competitive analysis assumes the same players will remain relevant. The trend analysis assumes current trajectories will continue. The strategy assumes the rules of competition will persist.

This is what I call presentism—the dangerous assumption that the future is simply an extension of the present. It's not a failure of intelligence. It's a failure of imagination. And it's built into virtually every tool of conventional business analysis.

The Kodak Paradox

Consider Eastman Kodak. In the 1970s and 1980s, Kodak was the gold standard of corporate excellence. They had extraordinary market share, massive R&D capabilities, and brilliant strategic planning processes. They benchmarked relentlessly. They understood their customers deeply. They improved their products continuously.

They also invented the digital camera.

Yes, Kodak invented the very technology that would destroy them. In 1975, Steve Sasson, a Kodak engineer, created the first digital camera prototype. Company executives looked at it and said, essentially: "That's interesting. But film is our business."
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
estroy them. In 1975, Steve Sasson, a Kodak engineer, created the first digital camera prototype. Company executives looked at it and said, essentially: "That's interesting. But film is our business."

They weren't stupid. They were rational. Digital cameras at the time were expensive, low-quality, and had no distribution infrastructure. Film was profitable, improving, and had an established ecosystem. By every conventional metric, doubling down on film was the smart move.

What they missed was that digital photography wasn't just another product improvement. It was a new dominant design—a fundamentally different architecture for capturing and sharing images. And once that architecture reached a certain threshold of capability and affordability, all of Kodak's advantages in the old system became irrelevant.

The film processing infrastructure? Worthless. The chemical expertise? Unneeded. The retail partnerships? Bypassed. The customer relationships built on a yearly cycle of vacation photos? Replaced by instant sharing.

Kodak didn't fail because they weren't competitive. They failed because they were competing brilliantly in a game that was ending.

The Gap That Dominant Designs Analysis Fills

This is the gap that conventional competitive analysis cannot fill. It can tell you how to compete within the current structure. It cannot tell you when the structure itself is about to shift.

Dominant Designs Analysis addresses this gap directly. It asks different questions:
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
ll you how to compete within the current structure. It cannot tell you when the structure itself is about to shift.

Dominant Designs Analysis addresses this gap directly. It asks different questions:

Where are the foundational assumptions of this industry being challenged?

What user frustrations are being ignored because they don't fit the current model?

What adjacent technologies or business models could disrupt the fundamental architecture?

What early experiments on the margins might represent the seeds of a new dominant design?

These questions don't replace conventional competitive analysis. They supplement it with something equally essential: the ability to recognize when the rules are about to change.

WHERE THIS THINKING COMES FROM

The Intellectual Foundation

The concept of dominant designs emerged from the study of technological evolution—specifically, from researchers trying to understand why certain technologies win out over alternatives and what happens when they're eventually displaced.

The intellectual roots trace back to the intersection of evolutionary economics, the sociology of technology, and innovation studies. Researchers observed that technological competition doesn't follow smooth curves of improvement. Instead, it exhibits punctuated patterns: long periods of incremental improvement within established architectures, interrupted by sudden shifts to entirely new architectures.
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
h curves of improvement. Instead, it exhibits punctuated patterns: long periods of incremental improvement within established architectures, interrupted by sudden shifts to entirely new architectures.

This pattern was not random. It had structure. And understanding that structure could help practitioners anticipate and prepare for transitions.

The Key Thinkers

William Abernathy and James Utterback laid the groundwork in the 1970s with their research on innovation patterns in the automobile and other industries. They observed that industries go through distinct phases: an early "fluid" phase where many competing designs exist, followed by the emergence of a dominant design, followed by a long period of incremental improvement focused on that design.

Their crucial insight was that once a dominant design emerges, the nature of competition changes fundamentally. Before the dominant design, companies compete on product architecture—on finding the best overall design. After the dominant design, companies compete on execution—on implementing the established design more efficiently, more reliably, more affordably.
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
duct architecture—on finding the best overall design. After the dominant design, companies compete on execution—on implementing the established design more efficiently, more reliably, more affordably.

Michael Tushman and Philip Anderson extended this work in their landmark 1986 paper "Technological Discontinuities and Dominant Designs," which introduced the concept of "eras of ferment"—the chaotic periods when an established dominant design is being challenged and a new one has not yet emerged. These eras, they showed, are when the greatest opportunities and risks exist.

Clayton Christensen added another crucial dimension with his research on disruptive innovation. He showed that dominant designs are often displaced not by superior technology, but by "good enough" technology that serves overlooked market segments or enables new business models. The disruption comes from the margins, not from direct competition.

Andy Grove, the legendary Intel CEO, brought these academic insights into practical application with his concept of "strategic inflection points"—moments when the fundamentals of a business shift and companies must adapt or die. His book "Only the Paranoid Survive" became a manual for executives navigating dominant design transitions.

From Academic Theory to Innovation Practice

From Academic Theory to Innovation Practice

The transition from academic theory to practical innovation tool happened gradually through the work of practitioners who recognized that understanding dominant design dynamics could provide competitive advantage.

The key insight for practitioners was this: dominant design transitions are not random events. They have predictable precursors. They follow recognizable patterns. And they create predictable opportunities for those who can read the signs.

The precursors include:

User complaints that incumbents dismiss as unreasonable or uninformed

Fringe experiments that established players consider irrelevant or impractical

Influential early adopters who embrace alternatives despite their limitations

Emerging technologies that could eventually solve problems the current design cannot address

Business model innovations that change the economics of the industry

By systematically scanning for these precursors, innovators can identify dominant design transitions before they become obvious—and position themselves to benefit from the transformation.

Why the Foundation Matters

Understanding where this thinking comes from isn't merely academic exercise. It provides crucial context for applying the tool effectively.

Why the Foundation Matters

Understanding where this thinking comes from isn't merely academic exercise. It provides crucial context for applying the tool effectively.

First, it reminds us that dominant design analysis is not speculation or prediction. It's based on observable patterns that have repeated across industries and time periods. The patterns are robust because they reflect fundamental dynamics of technological and market evolution.

Second, it provides frameworks for distinguishing genuine dominant design shifts from ordinary competitive dynamics. Not every new technology represents a dominant design transition. Not every startup represents disruption. The intellectual foundation helps us separate signal from noise.

Third, it connects dominant design analysis to a broader ecosystem of innovation tools. Scenario planning, trend analysis, disruptive innovation theory—these are all related approaches that address different aspects of the same fundamental challenge: anticipating and preparing for structural change.

THE DOMINANT DESIGNS FRAMEWORK

What We Mean By Dominant Design

A dominant design is a fundamental architecture that industry players collectively adopt because it solves multiple problems simultaneously, balancing practicality, cost, and user acceptance.

This definition has several crucial elements worth unpacking:
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
ndustry players collectively adopt because it solves multiple problems simultaneously, balancing practicality, cost, and user acceptance.

This definition has several crucial elements worth unpacking:

"Fundamental architecture" means we're not talking about specific products or features. We're talking about the underlying structure—the set of core components, their relationships, and the interfaces between them. The IBM PC architecture wasn't a specific computer; it was a standardized way of organizing processor, memory, storage, display, and input components that enabled an entire ecosystem.

"Industry players collectively adopt" means dominant designs are social phenomena, not just technological ones. A dominant design emerges when multiple companies, suppliers, customers, regulators, and complementors align around a common approach. This alignment creates powerful network effects and switching costs that reinforce the dominant design's position.

"Solves multiple problems simultaneously" means dominant designs win not because they're optimal for any single criterion, but because they represent workable compromises across many competing demands. The QWERTY keyboard isn't the fastest layout for typing, but it works well enough while also preventing mechanical jamming (the original design constraint) and enabling a standardized training approach.

content:
e QWERTY keyboard isn't the fastest layout for typing, but it works well enough while also preventing mechanical jamming (the original design constraint) and enabling a standardized training approach.

"Balancing practicality, cost, and user acceptance" acknowledges that dominant designs must satisfy technical, economic, and social requirements. A technically superior design that's too expensive or too difficult to adopt won't become dominant. Neither will an affordable, easy-to-use design that doesn't actually solve the underlying problem.

The Three Core Principles

Principle 1: Dominant Designs Are Temporary

Every dominant design eventually faces obsolescence. The very features that made it successful create blind spots. The compromises that enabled wide adoption also limit what's possible. The ecosystem that reinforces it also makes it rigid.

The internal combustion engine was a brilliant solution for personal transportation in the 20th century. But the infrastructure and expertise built around it also created resistance to alternatives. The automotive industry's skills, supply chains, dealerships, repair infrastructure, and fueling networks are all optimized for internal combustion. This creates powerful incentives to defend the existing architecture rather than embrace alternatives.
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
alerships, repair infrastructure, and fueling networks are all optimized for internal combustion. This creates powerful incentives to defend the existing architecture rather than embrace alternatives.

Example: The incandescent light bulb dominated for over a century. It was cheap to manufacture, well-understood, supported by massive infrastructure. But it converted only 5% of electricity to light, with 95% wasted as heat. LED technology, initially expensive and limited in applications, eventually became good enough on the dimensions that mattered while being dramatically superior on energy efficiency. The dominant design that seemed eternal fell in less than two decades.

Principle 2: Transitions Follow Recognizable Patterns

Dominant design transitions don't happen overnight or randomly. They follow an observable sequence:

Era of Incremental Improvement: The dominant design is stable. Competition focuses on efficiency, cost reduction, and minor feature improvements. Incumbents thrive.

Emergence of Signals: User frustrations accumulate. Fringe experiments appear. Adjacent technologies mature. Early adopters begin exploring alternatives. Most industry participants dismiss these signals.

Era of Ferment: Multiple alternatives compete. Uncertainty is high. Some incumbents experiment while others defend the status quo. New entrants arrive. The industry becomes chaotic.

ss these signals.

Era of Ferment: Multiple alternatives compete. Uncertainty is high. Some incumbents experiment while others defend the status quo. New entrants arrive. The industry becomes chaotic.

New Dominant Design Emerges: One architecture wins out (not necessarily the technically best one). Competition shifts back to execution. A new period of incremental improvement begins.

Example: The transition from film to digital photography followed this pattern precisely. Through the 1990s, film photography improved incrementally while digital cameras remained expensive curiosities. By the early 2000s, digital cameras had become "good enough" for casual photography, and an era of ferment began. Multiple digital formats competed. Camera manufacturers scrambled to adapt. By the late 2000s, the smartphone camera emerged as the new dominant design, and a new era of incremental improvement began—this time focused on computational photography, AI enhancement, and social sharing.

Principle 3: Opportunities Concentrate at Transition Points

The greatest opportunities for innovation and market entry exist during the era of ferment—after the old dominant design begins weakening but before the new one is established.

During stable periods, incumbents have overwhelming advantages: established customer relationships, optimized processes, accumulated expertise, ecosystem control. Competing with them directly is extremely difficult.

eriods, incumbents have overwhelming advantages: established customer relationships, optimized processes, accumulated expertise, ecosystem control. Competing with them directly is extremely difficult.

During transitions, these advantages become liabilities. Established customer relationships may be with the wrong customers. Optimized processes may produce the wrong outputs. Accumulated expertise may be in declining skills. Ecosystem control may lock companies into dying architectures.

Example: When Netflix began streaming video, established video rental chains had enormous advantages: prime real estate locations, customer databases, efficient logistics systems. But these advantages were optimized for physical distribution. As the dominant design shifted to streaming, Blockbuster's store locations became expensive liabilities, their logistics expertise became irrelevant, and their customer relationships couldn't transfer to a digital model. Netflix's "disadvantage" of having no physical infrastructure became an advantage—they had nothing to defend and everything to gain.

Key Concepts and Terminology

Era of Ferment: A chaotic period when multiple new ideas compete for dominance after an established design begins to falter. This is when the greatest opportunities exist—and when the greatest risks emerge.
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change

content:
Ferment: A chaotic period when multiple new ideas compete for dominance after an established design begins to falter. This is when the greatest opportunities exist—and when the greatest risks emerge.

Technological Discontinuity: A game-changing innovation that can displace existing norms and established designs overnight. Not all innovations are discontinuities; most are incremental improvements within the existing architecture.

Network Effects: The phenomenon where a design becomes more valuable as more users adopt it, contributing to its dominance. Network effects can protect dominant designs far past their technical superiority—but they can also accelerate transitions once a tipping point is reached.

Switching Costs: The expenses and effort required to change from one design to another. High switching costs often maintain dominant designs' position even when alternatives are technically superior.

Inflection Point: The moment when a dominant design begins showing signs of weakness through user complaints, fringe experiments, or influential endorsements. Recognizing inflection points early is the key skill in dominant designs analysis.

Market Saturation: The point where a dominant design meets or exceeds typical user needs, creating opportunity for alternative solutions that may be "worse" on traditional metrics but better on overlooked dimensions.

Presentism: The tendency to focus on current experiences, ignoring historical context or future possibilities. The most dangerous assumption in strategy is that tomorrow will look like today.

Why It Works: The Mechanism

Dominant designs analysis works because it addresses a fundamental asymmetry in how organizations perceive change.

Established organizations are highly attuned to competitive dynamics within the current structure. They track market share shifts, monitor competitor moves, and respond to price changes. Their information systems, incentive structures, and strategic planning processes are all designed to compete effectively within the existing game.

But these same systems are poorly designed to detect structural change. Market share data doesn't reveal when the market itself is becoming irrelevant. Competitor analysis doesn't capture threats from adjacent industries or new business models. Customer feedback tends to focus on improvements within the current paradigm rather than identifying when the paradigm itself is becoming obsolete.

Dominant designs analysis provides a systematic approach to detecting structural change by focusing specifically on the precursors of dominant design transitions:
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
aradigm itself is becoming obsolete.

Dominant designs analysis provides a systematic approach to detecting structural change by focusing specifically on the precursors of dominant design transitions:

What assumptions underlie the current dominant design? Every dominant design embodies assumptions about what customers want, what technologies can do, what business models work. Making these assumptions explicit enables examination of whether they still hold.

What user frustrations are being dismissed? The complaints that incumbents dismiss as unreasonable or uninformed often reveal limitations of the current dominant design. When users consistently want something the current design cannot provide, a transition may be approaching.

What experiments are happening on the margins? Fringe experiments that established players consider irrelevant often contain the seeds of future dominant designs. Paying attention to what's being tried—not just what's succeeding—provides early warning.

What enabling conditions are changing? Dominant design transitions often require enabling conditions: new technologies, regulatory changes, demographic shifts, infrastructure development. Tracking these conditions reveals when transitions become possible.

Who are the early adopters of alternatives? The people who embrace alternatives despite their current limitations often have insight into where the future is heading. Understanding why they're adopting suboptimal solutions reveals unmet needs.

The people who embrace alternatives despite their current limitations often have insight into where the future is heading. Understanding why they're adopting suboptimal solutions reveals unmet needs.

By systematically examining these dimensions, dominant designs analysis provides early warning of structural change that conventional competitive analysis misses.

WHY DOMINANT DESIGNS ANALYSIS MATTERS FOR INNOVATION

Reason 1: It Reveals Hidden Opportunities

The most valuable innovation opportunities are often invisible to conventional analysis because they exist in the spaces between dominant designs—either in the cracks of an aging architecture or in the emergence of a new one.

When a dominant design is stable, the obvious opportunities are incremental improvements within that design. Companies compete to make the existing solution cheaper, faster, more reliable. These opportunities are real, but they're also visible to everyone. Competition is fierce, margins are compressed, and truly differentiated positions are rare.

The hidden opportunities exist at the boundaries:

Serving users who don't fit the dominant design well. Every dominant design represents compromises. Some user segments are underserved by those compromises. Identifying these segments and serving them with alternatives creates opportunity.
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
t design well. Every dominant design represents compromises. Some user segments are underserved by those compromises. Identifying these segments and serving them with alternatives creates opportunity.

Solving problems the dominant design creates. Dominant designs solve some problems but create others. The automobile solved transportation but created parking problems, traffic congestion, pollution. Each created problem is a potential opportunity.

Preparing for the next dominant design. When transition signals appear, early positioning in potential new architectures creates option value. Even uncertain bets on future architectures can be highly valuable if the transition materializes.

Example: Southwest Airlines didn't compete directly with major carriers on the dominant design of hub-and-spoke networks with full service. Instead, they served the underserved segment of price-sensitive travelers with point-to-point flights and no-frills service. This wasn't a temporary competitive position—it was an alternative architecture that eventually became its own dominant design for short-haul travel.

Without this: Companies become trapped competing for incremental improvements within crowded markets, missing the structural opportunities that create breakthrough returns.

Reason 2: It Provides Strategic Early Warning

Dominant designs analysis provides early warning of industry transitions—often years or decades before they become obvious to conventional analysis.
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
ns.

Reason 2: It Provides Strategic Early Warning

Dominant designs analysis provides early warning of industry transitions—often years or decades before they become obvious to conventional analysis.

This early warning creates strategic options that don't exist once transitions become apparent. When everyone recognizes that an industry is in transition, entry barriers are low (everyone is scrambling), uncertainty is maximum (no one knows what's next), and competitive pressure is intense (many players are chasing the same opportunities).

When you recognize a transition early, you can:

Build capabilities before they're in demand. The skills, relationships, and infrastructure needed for a new dominant design take time to develop. Early recognition enables early investment.

Acquire positions while they're undervalued. During stable periods, assets optimized for alternative architectures are often available cheaply. Once transitions become apparent, these same assets become expensive or unavailable.

Shape the emerging architecture. Early participants in emerging dominant designs often influence how they develop. Late entrants must accept architectures designed by others.
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
xpensive or unavailable.

Shape the emerging architecture. Early participants in emerging dominant designs often influence how they develop. Late entrants must accept architectures designed by others.

Example: Amazon Web Services launched in 2006, when most companies still viewed computing infrastructure as something you owned rather than rented. AWS recognized that internet-based business models would create demand for elastic, pay-as-you-go computing—a new dominant design for IT infrastructure. By the time the transition became obvious, AWS had an insurmountable lead.

Without this: Companies react to transitions after they're obvious, competing with many others for the same late-stage opportunities, often with inadequate capabilities and at maximum prices.

Reason 3: It Prevents Defensive Traps

One of the most dangerous responses to an emerging dominant design transition is to defend the existing architecture rather than embrace the new one.

This defensive response is psychologically natural and often economically rational in the short term. Existing architectures represent massive investments. Companies have built capabilities, relationships, and processes optimized for the current design. Shareholders expect returns from these investments. Defending them seems logical.
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
massive investments. Companies have built capabilities, relationships, and processes optimized for the current design. Shareholders expect returns from these investments. Defending them seems logical.

But defensive responses often accelerate decline rather than prevent it. Resources devoted to defending the old architecture are unavailable for building capabilities in the new one. Customer relationships built on the old value proposition may not transfer to new offerings. Perhaps most importantly, the organizational culture becomes oriented toward preservation rather than innovation.

Dominant designs analysis helps prevent defensive traps by:

Making transitions visible earlier. When transitions are distant and uncertain, the costs of defensive responses are low. When transitions are immediate and obvious, the costs of switching are high. Early visibility enables earlier, less costly transitions.

Framing transitions as opportunities rather than threats. The same transition that threatens existing businesses creates opportunities for new ones—often within the same company. Dominant designs analysis focuses attention on the opportunity side.

Identifying transfer assets. Not all existing capabilities become worthless in transitions. Customer relationships, brand equity, distribution capabilities, and technical expertise often have value in new architectures. Identifying these transfer assets enables more effective transitions.
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
s. Customer relationships, brand equity, distribution capabilities, and technical expertise often have value in new architectures. Identifying these transfer assets enables more effective transitions.

Example: Netflix provides a counter-example to Blockbuster's defensive trap. Netflix began as a DVD-by-mail service—still within the physical distribution dominant design. But Reed Hastings recognized that streaming represented a new dominant design and systematically shifted the company toward it, cannibalizing their own DVD business in the process. This willingness to embrace transition rather than defend the existing business enabled Netflix to lead the new architecture rather than be displaced by it.

Without this: Companies often recognize transitions too late, respond defensively, and accelerate their own decline—a pattern visible in countless industry disruptions.

Reason 4: It Enables Portfolio Strategy

Dominant designs analysis enables a portfolio approach to innovation investment that balances exploitation of current architectures with exploration of emerging ones.

Most innovation portfolios are implicitly weighted toward the current dominant design. Incremental improvement projects are low-risk and high-certainty. They leverage existing capabilities and serve existing customers. They're easy to justify and easy to measure.
title: DOMINANT DESIGNS  Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change
source_file: DOMINANT DESIGNS_ Recognizing When the Rules Are About to Change.docx

content:
urrent dominant design. Incremental improvement projects are low-risk and high-certainty. They leverage existing capabilities and serve existing customers. They're easy to justify and easy to measure.

Investments in potential new dominant designs are riskier and more uncertain. They require new capabilities and may serve new customers. They're harder to justify and harder to measure. As a result, they tend to be underfunded.

Dominant designs analysis provides a framework for rebalancing:

Categorizing investments by dominant design. Explicitly labeling investments as "current architecture" or "potential new architecture" makes the portfolio visible and enables deliberate rebalancing.

Sizing investments to transition probability. As transition signals strengthen, investments in new architectures should increase. Dominant designs analysis provides a framework for reading these signals.

Valuing optionality. Investments in potential new architectures create options—the right but not the obligation to expand if the transition materializes. Dominant designs analysis helps value these options appropriately.

Example: Amazon's investment portfolio explicitly balances exploitation of current businesses with exploration of potential new ones. AWS, Alexa, and Amazon Go all represent bets on potential new dominant designs. Not all will succeed, but the portfolio approach ensures that Amazon has positions in multiple possible futures.

w ones. AWS, Alexa, and Amazon Go all represent bets on potential new dominant designs. Not all will succeed, but the portfolio approach ensures that Amazon has positions in multiple possible futures.

Without this: Innovation portfolios become unbalanced toward the current dominant design, leaving companies vulnerable to transitions and without positions in emerging architectures.

THE DOMINANT DESIGNS METHOD: 6 STEPS

STEP 1: Map the Current Dominant Design

Objective: Explicitly articulate the fundamental architecture that currently structures your industry or domain.

Actions:

Identify the core components that define how value is created and delivered

Map the relationships between these components

Articulate the key interfaces and standards

Document the assumptions embedded in the current design

Identify the major players and their positions within the architecture

Questions to Ask:

What are the fundamental components of the current value chain?

What standards or protocols enable interoperability?

What assumptions about customer needs underlie this design?

What capabilities does success within this design require?

Who benefits most from the current architecture?

Example Output:

Industry: Traditional Higher Education

Key Assumptions:

CASE STUDIES

Case Study 1: Intel's Strategic Inflection Point — Success

The Challenge:

In the mid-1980s, Intel was primarily a memory chip company. Their Dynamic Random Access Memory (DRAM) chips were their flagship product, and the company had built its identity, capabilities, and relationships around memory chip design and manufacturing.

But the memory chip market was transforming. Japanese manufacturers had entered with massive government support, superior quality control, and a willingness to compete on price that Intel couldn't match. Intel's market share was collapsing. Losses were mounting. The company that had pioneered the memory chip market was being driven out of it.

What made this situation particularly challenging:

What made this situation particularly challenging:

Memory chips weren't just Intel's main product—they were Intel's identity. The company's culture, expertise, and self-image were built around being the memory chip leader.

Intel had made substantial investments in memory chip manufacturing that would become worthless if they exited the business.

Microprocessors, while growing, were still a small part of Intel's business. Betting the company on them was highly risky.

The Application:

Andy Grove and Gordon Moore famously asked themselves: "If we got kicked out and the board brought in a new CEO, what would he do?" The answer was obvious: exit memory chips and focus on microprocessors.

This was dominant designs analysis in action, though not using that terminology. Grove recognized that:

The memory chip dominant design was being commoditized. Japanese manufacturers had achieved cost and quality advantages that couldn't be overcome.

A new dominant design was emerging around personal computers, and microprocessors would be the critical component.

Intel had accumulated capabilities in microprocessor design that could become the foundation for a new strategic position.

The Key Insight:

Intel had accumulated capabilities in microprocessor design that could become the foundation for a new strategic position.

The Key Insight:

Intel's competitive advantage wasn't in memory chip manufacturing—it was in complex integrated circuit design. This capability was more valuable in microprocessors than in commoditized memory chips. The transition wasn't about abandoning Intel's strengths; it was about applying those strengths to a more valuable architecture.

The Impact:

Intel became synonymous with microprocessors, achieving near-monopoly positions in PC and server processors that persisted for decades.

The Lesson:

Dominant design transitions create opportunities to redefine competitive position. Intel's capabilities didn't change—but their application did. By recognizing the transition and repositioning accordingly, Intel transformed from a declining commodity supplier to an industry-defining monopolist.

Case Study 2: Encyclopedia Britannica — Failure

The Challenge:

For over two centuries, Encyclopedia Britannica was the gold standard of knowledge compilation. Founded in 1768, it represented the dominant design for authoritative reference information: expert-written articles, comprehensive coverage, physical volumes, door-to-door sales.

owledge compilation. Founded in 1768, it represented the dominant design for authoritative reference information: expert-written articles, comprehensive coverage, physical volumes, door-to-door sales.

In 1990, Britannica was at its peak—a $650 million business selling $1,500 encyclopedia sets to millions of households. Their sales force was legendary, their brand was impeccable, and their competitive position seemed unassailable.

Within a decade, the company had collapsed. Revenues fell by over 80%. The sales force was eliminated. The company was sold and resold at declining valuations.

What happened?

First, CD-ROM encyclopedias (particularly Microsoft Encarta) emerged. They were cheaper ($50 vs $1,500), easier to search, and took up no shelf space. Britannica dismissed them—the content was inferior, the articles were shorter, the expertise was questionable.

Then Wikipedia emerged. It was free, constantly updated, and covered topics Britannica never would. Britannica dismissed it even more forcefully—anyone could edit it, there was no quality control, it couldn't possibly compete with expert curation.

The Application (That Didn't Happen):

Britannica failed to recognize that the dominant design for reference information was shifting from:

Expert curation → Community creation

Fixed publication → Continuous update

Premium pricing → Free access

Physical distribution → Digital delivery

The Key Insight:

Britannica's response was entirely defensive. They created a CD-ROM version (too little, too late). They launched a website (behind a paywall when competitors were free). They defended their expert-driven model while users demonstrated they valued accessibility over authority.

The Impact:

The company that defined authoritative knowledge became an also-ran, known more for what it used to be than for what it is.

The Lesson:

Dominant design transitions can destroy market leaders who fail to recognize them. Britannica's expertise, brand, and sales capabilities—enormous advantages under the old design—became irrelevant or even liabilities under the new one. Their defensive response accelerated rather than prevented decline.

Case Study 3: Netflix's Three Transitions — Complex Application

The Challenge:

Netflix provides a remarkable example of a company that has successfully navigated multiple dominant design transitions—not by defending its position, but by repeatedly cannibalizing its own business model.

Transition 1: Video Rental → DVD-by-Mail

In 1997, the video rental dominant design was epitomized by Blockbuster: retail stores with broad selection, late fees for returns, weekend-focused consumption. Netflix entered with an alternative architecture: DVD-by-mail with no late fees, queue-based selection, monthly subscription.

This wasn't just a different product—it was a different architecture for video rental. No stores meant lower costs but delayed gratification. No late fees changed the consumption pattern. Subscription pricing changed the economics.

Transition 2: DVD-by-Mail → Streaming

By 2007, Netflix's DVD business was thriving. But Reed Hastings recognized that streaming represented a new dominant design—instant access, unlimited consumption, device flexibility. Despite having built substantial infrastructure for DVD distribution, Netflix invested heavily in streaming, eventually making it the primary business.

ADVANCED CONCEPTS AND MENTAL MODELS

Mental Model 1: The S-Curve of Improvement

Dominant designs follow S-curves of improvement. Early performance improvements are slow as the design is being refined. Middle-stage improvements are rapid as the design is optimized. Late-stage improvements are slow again as the design approaches fundamental limits.

Application: Track where the current dominant design is on its S-curve. Slow improvement late in the curve suggests the design is approaching limits and transition may be near. Rapid improvement in the middle of the curve suggests the design is healthy and transition is less imminent.

Example: Smartphone camera improvement followed a classic S-curve. Early cameras improved slowly (2-5 megapixels). Middle-stage improvements were rapid (better sensors, multiple lenses, computational photography). Current improvements are slowing—cameras are "good enough" for most users, suggesting the architecture may be approaching maturity.

Mental Model 2: Overshooting and Underserved Segments

As dominant designs mature, they often overshoot the needs of mainstream customers while continuing to underserve specific segments. This creates openings for alternatives that may be "worse" by traditional metrics but better for overlooked needs.

Application: Ask what dimensions of performance the current design is overshooting. Then ask what segments would trade that excess performance for something else—lower cost, greater simplicity, different features.

Example: Enterprise software became increasingly complex and feature-rich, overshooting the needs of small businesses and individual users. This created openings for simpler alternatives (Basecamp vs. Microsoft Project, Slack vs. Lotus Notes) that traded features for usability.

Mental Model 3: The Sailing Ship Effect

When new technologies threaten established ones, incumbents often respond with accelerated improvement of the old technology. This can create a temporary period where the old technology improves faster than it ever did before—even as it's being displaced.

Application: Don't be fooled by accelerated improvement in the old design. This "sailing ship effect" (named after how sailing ships improved dramatically after steam ships appeared) is often a sign that transition is near, not that the old design is healthy.

Mental Model 4: Architectural Knowledge vs. Component Knowledge

Companies develop two types of knowledge: component knowledge (how to make specific parts better) and architectural knowledge (how parts fit together). Dominant design transitions often preserve component knowledge while destroying architectural knowledge.

Application: Inventory your knowledge portfolio. Which knowledge is component-level and therefore potentially transferable? Which is architectural-level and therefore at risk in a transition? This helps identify what capabilities might transfer to a new dominant design.

Example: Kodak had world-class component knowledge in imaging sensors—transferable to digital photography. But their architectural knowledge about film processing, chemical development, and retail distribution was worthless in the digital world.

Mental Model 5: Windows of Opportunity

Dominant design transitions create windows of opportunity—periods when the old advantages are weakening but the new ones aren't yet established. These windows eventually close as a new dominant design consolidates.

Application: Assess where you are in the transition timeline. Early positioning requires accepting higher uncertainty but offers the possibility of shaping the new architecture. Late positioning offers more certainty but less ability to influence outcomes.

Example: The window for electric vehicle manufacturers to establish position is closing. Early entrants like Tesla shaped the emerging architecture (charging networks, software-defined vehicles, direct sales). Late entrants must accept that architecture rather than shape it.

Regulatory Preservation: Some dominant designs persist not because they're optimal but because regulations protect them. When regulatory barriers fall, transitions can be sudden and dramatic.

COMMON MISTAKES

MISTAKE 1: Confusing Product Competition with Dominant Design Transition

The Problem: Treating ordinary competitive dynamics as dominant design transitions. Not every new product or business model represents an architectural shift.

The Reality Check: True dominant design transitions affect the fundamental structure of an industry—the components, interfaces, standards, and assumptions that define how value is created. Product competition within a stable architecture is normal competitive dynamics.

The Fix: Ask whether the change affects the architecture itself or just specific products within the existing architecture. If existing capabilities and assets remain valuable, it's probably not a dominant design transition.

change affects the architecture itself or just specific products within the existing architecture. If existing capabilities and assets remain valuable, it's probably not a dominant design transition.

Example: The smartphone price war between Apple and Samsung is product competition within a stable dominant design. The shift from feature phones to smartphones was a dominant design transition.

MISTAKE 2: Overestimating Transition Speed

The Problem: Assuming transitions will happen faster than they actually do. Early signals of transition often appear years or decades before the transition materializes.

The Reality Check: Dominant design transitions require not just technological possibility but also infrastructure development, ecosystem formation, regulatory accommodation, and behavioral change. These take time.

The Fix: Explicitly assess the enabling conditions for transition. What infrastructure must be built? What regulations must change? What behaviors must shift? Time your positioning to match realistic transition timelines.

Example: Electric vehicles were "imminent" for decades before the transition actually accelerated. Only when battery costs, charging infrastructure, and consumer acceptance reached critical thresholds did the transition materialize.

MISTAKE 3: Applying Old Metrics to New Designs

The Problem: Evaluating emerging designs using the metrics of the current dominant design. This makes alternatives look inadequate on dimensions they're not trying to compete on.

The Reality Check: New dominant designs often succeed by prioritizing different dimensions than current ones. Digital cameras initially had worse image quality than film but offered instant review and sharing. Streaming initially had worse selection than DVD rental but offered instant access.

The Fix: Identify what dimensions the alternative is optimizing for. Evaluate it on those dimensions, not on the dimensions the current design optimizes for.

Example: MOOCs looked inadequate compared to university education on completion rates and depth of instruction. But they optimized for accessibility and cost—dimensions traditional education wasn't addressing.

MISTAKE 4: Waiting for Certainty

The Problem: Delaying action until the new dominant design is clear. By then, early movers have established positions and the opportunity window has closed.

The Reality Check: The era of ferment—when multiple alternatives compete—is precisely when positioning creates most value. Waiting for certainty means accepting the positions established by others.

The Fix: Develop a portfolio of experiments across multiple potential architectures. Accept uncertainty about which will win while building capabilities and positions that provide optionality.

Example: Companies that waited until streaming clearly dominated to invest in streaming capabilities found themselves far behind Netflix. The time to invest was during uncertainty, not after resolution.

MISTAKE 5: Defending Rather Than Transitioning

The Problem: Responding to dominant design transitions by defending the existing architecture rather than building capabilities in the new one.

The Reality Check: Defensive responses rarely succeed because they divert resources from building new capabilities while the transition continues regardless.

The Fix: Allocate resources to new architecture development even while maintaining existing business. Cannibalize yourself before competitors do. Accept that existing advantages may become liabilities.

Example: Kodak's defensive response—continuing to invest in film while half-heartedly exploring digital—accelerated their decline. A more aggressive pivot to digital, even at the cost of the film business, might have preserved their position.

MISTAKE 6: Ignoring Marginal Experiments

The Problem: Dismissing experiments that don't appear to threaten the current business. "That's not our market" or "That technology isn't good enough" become excuses for ignoring early signals.

The Reality Check: New dominant designs often emerge from the margins. They start by serving segments or use cases the current design doesn't address well. By the time they're good enough for mainstream applications, the transition is well underway.

The Fix: Systematically scan for marginal experiments. Ask what they're optimizing for and who they're serving. Track their improvement trajectories. Consider whether they might eventually serve mainstream needs.

Example: Blockbuster dismissed Netflix's DVD-by-mail service as serving a niche of "movie enthusiasts." By the time they recognized it as a threat, Netflix had established the customer relationships and capabilities that enabled their streaming pivot.

ISTAKE 7: Underestimating Ecosystem Effects

The Problem: Analyzing dominant design transitions in isolation, without considering the broader ecosystem of suppliers, complementors, and infrastructure.

The Reality Check: Dominant designs don't exist in isolation. They're embedded in ecosystems of related players whose positions also change during transitions. Ecosystem dynamics can accelerate or delay transitions.

The Fix: Map the ecosystem around the current dominant design. Identify which players benefit from the current architecture and which would benefit from alternatives. Consider how ecosystem dynamics affect transition timing and direction.

Example: The smartphone transition accelerated because app developers, telecom carriers, and accessory makers all benefited from the new architecture. Electric vehicle transition depends on charging infrastructure, service networks, and electrical grid capacity.

THE ULTIMATE DOMINANT DESIGNS QUESTION

There's one question that separates those who truly understand Dominant Designs Analysis from those who merely go through the motions:

"What assumptions underlying our industry's current architecture are we failing to question—and who is building an alternative?"

This question demands uncomfortable honesty. It requires admitting that the rules you've mastered might be changing. It requires acknowledging that outsiders might see opportunities you're blind to. It requires accepting that your advantages might be temporary.

Great innovators don't just answer this question once. They make it a discipline. They systematically challenge the assumptions embedded in their industry's architecture. They deliberately seek out experiments that could represent alternatives. They maintain peripheral vision even when focused on current business.

Andy Grove's "only the paranoid survive" captures this mindset. Not paranoia about competitors within the current game—that's standard competitive awareness. Paranoia about whether the game itself is changing.

The companies and individuals who thrive through dominant design transitions are those who constantly ask: What architecture would we build if we were starting fresh today? And who might actually be building it?

This question should haunt your work in the best possible way.

FINAL THOUGHT

Dominant designs are the invisible architectures that structure competition. They define what's possible, what's valuable, and who wins. Understanding them provides insight not just into how industries work today, but into how they might transform tomorrow.

The skill isn't predicting which architecture will win. The skill is recognizing when the rules are becoming uncertain and positioning yourself to benefit from multiple possible futures.

MACRO-CHANGES: HARNESSING THE FORCES OF DISRUPTION

Finding Problems Worth Solving in the Wreckage of Transformation

By Lawrence Aronhime

OPENING PROVOCATION

Here's a question that should terrify every executive in the room:

What is being destroyed right now in your industry that will create the biggest opportunities of the next decade?

Most people hear "disruption" and think about threats—new competitors, obsolete products, changing customer preferences. They play defense. They try to protect what they have.

This is exactly backward.

Every macro-change that destroys something also creates something. The same forces that bankrupted Blockbuster made Netflix a $200 billion company. The same regulatory shifts that crippled taxi monopolies enabled Uber to capture $100 billion in value. The same social changes that emptied shopping malls created a logistics empire for Amazon.

The question isn't whether massive changes are coming to your industry. They are. The question is whether you will be the destroyer or the destroyed.

This is Macro-Changes—a systematic method for identifying the political, economic, social, and technological forces that are actively dismantling current paradigms, and finding the problems worth solving in what remains.

Most innovators wait until disruption arrives. By then, it's too late. This tool lets you see disruption coming years before it materializes—and position yourself to capitalize on it.

THE PROBLEM WITH CONVENTIONAL TREND ANALYSIS

THE PROBLEM WITH CONVENTIONAL TREND ANALYSIS

Let me tell you why most organizations fail at anticipating change.

The Passive Observer Trap

Imagine a retail executive in 2007. They see trends clearly enough: e-commerce is growing, smartphones are emerging, social media is taking off. They commission a beautiful PowerPoint about "digital transformation." They nod thoughtfully in strategy meetings.

And then they watch their company collapse.

The problem wasn't that they didn't see the trends. The problem was that they treated trends as information to be monitored rather than forces to be exploited.

Conventional trend analysis asks: "What is happening?"

Macro-Changes analysis asks: "What is being destroyed, and what opportunities does that destruction create?"

The Incremental Improvement Disease

Most companies respond to macro-changes incrementally. A bookstore sees Amazon growing, so they improve their inventory management. A newspaper sees digital media rising, so they create a website. A taxi company sees ride-sharing emerging, so they build an app.

These are all reasonable responses. They're also completely inadequate.

When macro-forces are at work, incremental improvement is a slow path to irrelevance.

The companies that win during macro-disruptions don't make their existing models slightly better. They identify what the macro-change is destroying, then build something entirely new on the rubble.

The Single-Force Blindness

Here's another fatal error: analyzing macro-changes in isolation.

A technology company focuses obsessively on technological change—and gets blindsided by regulatory change. A pharmaceutical company monitors regulatory change—and misses social changes in patient expectations. A financial services company tracks economic indicators—and fails to anticipate political backlash against their industry.

Macro-changes don't happen in silos. They interact, amplify, and compound each other. The COVID-19 pandemic was a health crisis that triggered economic disruption, accelerated technological adoption, shifted social behavior, and created political upheaval—all simultaneously.

To see the full picture, you need a systematic framework that captures all dimensions of macro-change.

That's what PEST analysis provides.

WHERE THIS THINKING COMES FROM

The Origins of Environmental Scanning

The intellectual foundation of Macro-Changes analysis traces back to the 1960s, when scholars began developing systematic approaches to analyzing organizational environments.

The intellectual foundation of Macro-Changes analysis traces back to the 1960s, when scholars began developing systematic approaches to analyzing organizational environments.

Francis Aguilar, a Harvard Business School professor, introduced the ETPS framework (Economic, Technical, Political, Social) in his 1967 book Scanning the Business Environment. This was revolutionary: for the first time, strategists had a structured way to think about the external forces shaping their industries.

Over the following decades, scholars refined and expanded the framework. Arnold Brown reorganized it as STEP, then PEST (Political, Economic, Social, Technological). Later variations added Environmental and Legal factors (PESTLE) or Regulatory considerations (STEEPLERS).

The McKinsey Acceleration

The theoretical framework gained practical urgency in 2015 when McKinsey Global Institute published No Ordinary Disruption: The Four Great Disruption Forces Breaking All the Trends.

Authors Richard Dobbs, James Manyika, and Jonathan Woetzel documented four macro-forces reshaping the global economy:

The Shifting Locus of Economic Activity: The rise of emerging markets, urbanization, and new centers of economic power

The Acceleration of Technology: The exponential pace of technological change outstripping human intuition

The Aging World: Demographic shifts creating new pressures and opportunities

Their key insight: these forces are not operating sequentially or independently. They're happening simultaneously, interacting with each other, and creating compound effects that exceed any historical precedent.

From Analysis to Action: Rowan Gibson's Four Lenses

Rowan Gibson, in his work on innovation, positioned "Harnessing Trends" as one of the four fundamental lenses through which innovators see opportunities:

Challenging Orthodoxies: Questioning assumptions everyone takes for granted

Harnessing Trends: Exploiting macro-changes before competitors

Leveraging Resources: Finding new uses for existing capabilities

Understanding Needs: Uncovering unmet customer needs

Gibson's contribution was showing that trend analysis isn't just about prediction—it's about action. The goal isn't to forecast the future. The goal is to identify opportunities for innovation that others are missing.

Why This Matters for Innovators

The history matters because it reveals a crucial progression in thinking:

1960s: Environmental scanning as information gathering

1990s: PEST analysis as strategic planning tool

2015: Recognition that forces are accelerating and compounding

THE MACRO-CHANGES FRAMEWORK

What We Mean By Macro-Changes

A macro-change is a large-scale shift in the Political, Economic, Social, or Technological environment that has the power to:

Destroy existing business models, products, or services

Create new problems that didn't exist before

Shift value from incumbents to new entrants

Redefine what customers need and want

Not all changes qualify as macro-changes. A new competitor entering your market is a competitive threat, but it's not a macro-change. A technology that fundamentally alters how your industry operates is a macro-change.

The test: Would this change affect multiple industries, multiple geographies, or multiple customer segments? If yes, it's probably a macro-change.

The PEST Framework

PEST analysis provides a structured way to identify and categorize macro-changes:

POLITICAL

Regulatory changes (new laws, enforcement shifts)

Government policy (subsidies, taxes, trade agreements)

The Three Core Principles

Principle 1: Every Change Destroys—And Creates

When a macro-change occurs, it doesn't just threaten existing players. It creates entirely new problem spaces.

When smartphones destroyed the camera industry, they created:

The need for mobile-first photo management

The opportunity for social photo sharing

The demand for mobile photography accessories

The market for photo-based communication apps

Instagram, Snapchat, and GoPro all emerged from the destruction of Kodak's business model.

Your job is to identify what's being destroyed and find the problems worth solving in the aftermath.

Principle 2: Forces Interact and Compound

Macro-changes rarely operate in isolation. A technological change creates economic shifts which trigger political responses which alter social behavior.

Consider electric vehicles:

Technological: Battery costs dropping, charging infrastructure improving

Political: Government mandates, emissions regulations, subsidies

Economic: Lower operating costs, new financing models, grid infrastructure investment

Social: Environmental consciousness, status signaling, range anxiety acceptance

Analyzing any single dimension gives an incomplete picture. The opportunity lies at the intersections.

Principle 3: Timing Is Everything
