Principle 3: Timing Is Everything

Macro-changes unfold over years or decades, but opportunities to capitalize are often narrow windows.

Too early: The infrastructure isn't ready, customers aren't educated, complementary technologies don't exist

Too late: Incumbents have adapted, new entrants have captured the market, the opportunity has passed

Just right: The forces are aligned, the problem is acute, and the solution is feasible

The purpose of Macro-Changes analysis isn't just to identify forces—it's to determine when those forces will create actionable opportunities.

The Destruction-Opportunity Connection

This is the core insight of the Macro-Changes tool:

What is being destroyed → What problems does that create → What solutions does that enable

The innovators who win don't resist the destruction. They run toward it.

WHY MACRO-CHANGES MATTERS FOR INNOVATION

Reason 1: It Forces You to Look Where Others Won't

Most competitive analysis focuses on existing competitors, current customers, and known markets. Macro-Changes analysis forces you to look at the external forces that will reshape all of those.

The counter-intuitive truth: The biggest threats to your business probably don't come from your current competitors. They come from forces that will make your entire competitive frame obsolete.

Time to establish market position

Time to experiment and learn

Case Study 1: Shell and the 1973 Oil Crisis

The Challenge

In the early 1970s, Royal Dutch Shell was one of many oil companies enjoying stable, predictable markets. The "Seven Sisters" (major oil companies) dominated the industry, and most assumed the favorable conditions would continue indefinitely.

Tool Application

Tool Application

Shell's scenario planning team, led by Pierre Wack, applied what we would now call Macro-Changes analysis. They systematically examined:

Political: Rising nationalism in oil-producing countries; formation of OPEC; Israel-Arab tensions Economic: Western dependence on Middle Eastern oil; pricing power shifting to producers Social: Environmental consciousness emerging; energy conservation gaining attention Technological: Nuclear power development; alternative energy research

Key Insight

Unlike their competitors, Shell's team didn't try to predict which scenario would occur. Instead, they asked: What happens if the favorable conditions are destroyed?

They identified a critical discontinuity: If OPEC nations asserted control over pricing, the entire cost structure of the oil industry would shift overnight.

Impact Analysis

When the 1973 oil crisis hit, Shell was the only major oil company prepared. While competitors scrambled, Shell:

Had already developed energy conservation strategies

Had diversified geographically

Had built financial reserves

Had contingency plans for supply disruption

Shell moved from the weakest of the Seven Sisters to one of the two strongest—a position they maintained for decades.

Case Study 2: Kodak's Failure to Harness Technological Discontinuity

The Challenge

In 1975, Kodak engineer Steve Sasson invented the digital camera. Kodak had first-mover advantage on the most significant technological discontinuity in their industry's history.

What Kodak Saw

Kodak actually performed sophisticated analysis of digital imaging trends:

They accurately predicted digital would eventually dominate

They calculated the timeline (roughly 15-20 years)

They understood the technical trajectory

What Kodak Missed

Kodak's analysis was purely technological. They failed to examine:

Economic: How digital photography would destroy the recurring revenue model of film processing Social: How digital sharing would transform photography from preservation to communication Political: How intellectual property regimes would shift value capture

Kodak asked "How will the technology evolve?" instead of "What is this technology going to destroy?"

Technical trend analysis without PEST integration is dangerous. Kodak saw the technology but missed what it would destroy and what opportunities that destruction would create.

Mental Model 1: The Destruction Stack

Not all destruction is equal. Macro-changes create layers of destruction, and the opportunities at each layer are different:

Layer 1: Product Destruction Specific products become obsolete (e.g., film cameras, paper maps, CD players) Opportunity: Better products

Layer 2: Business Model Destruction Ways of making money stop working (e.g., advertising-supported local news, commission-based travel agencies) Opportunity: New business models

Layer 3: Industry Structure Destruction The entire value chain reconfigures (e.g., music industry, retail, media) Opportunity: New platforms and intermediaries

Layer 4: Paradigm Destruction Fundamental assumptions about how things work change (e.g., ownership vs. access, centralized vs. distributed) Opportunity: Category creation

Application: Analyze which layer the macro-changes you've identified are destroying. The deeper the layer, the bigger the opportunity—and the harder the execution.

Three factors determine whether a macro-change opportunity is actionable:

Force Magnitude: How powerful is the change? Is it a ripple or a tsunami?

Velocity: How fast is it moving? Gradual shift or sudden disruption?

COMMON MISTAKES

MISTAKE 1: Treating PEST as a Checklist Instead of a System

The Problem: Students identify Political factors, Economic factors, Social factors, and Technological factors—and then stop. They treat PEST as four separate boxes to fill in.

The Reality Check: The power of Macro-Changes analysis comes from seeing how forces interact. Isolated factors rarely create significant opportunities. Compound forces do.

The Fix: After identifying individual forces, explicitly map interactions. Ask: How does this Political change affect Economic factors? How do Economic changes influence Social behavior? Draw the connections.

Example: "AI regulation" (Political) is meaningless in isolation. Connected to "AI capability advancement" (Technological), "automation anxiety" (Social), and "productivity pressure" (Economic), it becomes a systems story with clear implications.

MISTAKE 2: Focusing on Threats Instead of Opportunities

The Problem: Macro-changes feel threatening. Students spend their analysis explaining why changes are bad for existing players.

The Reality Check: Every destruction creates opportunity. If your analysis produces only threats, you're doing defensive analysis, not innovation analysis.

The Fix: For every "this destroys X" statement, force yourself to complete: "which creates the opportunity for Y." No exceptions.

Example: "AI destroys entry-level legal work" → "which creates the opportunity for legal AI tools, human-in-the-loop verification systems, and high-touch legal concierge services."

MISTAKE 3: Confusing Trends with Macro-Changes

The Problem: Students identify trends (things that are growing or shrinking) without assessing whether they have the magnitude to create destruction and opportunity.

The Reality Check: Most trends are incremental. They'll affect existing players slightly but won't create new problem spaces. Macro-changes are transformative—they make certain things impossible and other things newly possible.

The Fix: Apply the destruction test: "What does this trend make impossible or obsolete?" If the answer is "nothing much," it's not a macro-change—it's just a trend.

The Problem: Students identify real macro-changes but ignore when they'll create actionable opportunities.

The Reality Check: A macro-change that will create opportunities in 20 years is strategically different from one that will create opportunities in 2 years. Both are real; only one is actionable now.

The Fix: Add timing assessment to every force. Is this happening now? 3-5 years? 10+ years? What signals would indicate acceleration or deceleration?

Example: "Autonomous vehicles will transform transportation" is true. But if full autonomy is 15+ years away, opportunities today are in driver assistance and fleet management, not robotaxi platforms.

The Problem: Students analyze macro-changes in their primary domain and miss forces from adjacent or upstream domains.

The Reality Check: The most significant macro-changes often originate outside your primary domain. Analyzing only your industry creates blind spots.

MISTAKE 7: Analysis Paralysis

The Problem: Students produce comprehensive PEST analyses with hundreds of forces identified—and then can't prioritize or act.

The Reality Check: Completeness is the enemy of action. You don't need to identify every force—you need to identify the forces that matter most.

The Fix: After initial scanning, ruthlessly prioritize. Use impact and certainty filters. Focus analysis on the top 3-5 forces with high impact and high-to-medium certainty. Leave the rest as monitoring items.

Example: A comprehensive PEST analysis of healthcare might identify 50+ forces. A useful analysis focuses on 3-5: regulatory shift toward value-based care, AI diagnostic capability, consumer cost-consciousness, labor shortage, and interoperability mandates. Everything else is context.

HISTORICAL CONTEXT: THE CASE FOR MACRO-CHANGES

The Shell Story: Seeing What Others Missed

In 1972, Royal Dutch Shell's scenario planning team saw what competitors couldn't see: OPEC nations would eventually assert control over oil pricing, destroying the comfortable assumptions that had governed the industry for decades.

Shell didn't predict the 1973 oil crisis. They didn't need to. By systematically analyzing political forces (rising nationalism), economic forces (Western dependence), social forces (environmental consciousness), and technological forces (alternative energy development), they identified that the favorable conditions could be destroyed—and prepared accordingly.

When the crisis hit, Shell was ready. They moved from the weakest of the "Seven Sisters" to one of the two strongest—a position maintained for decades.

The lesson: Systematic PEST analysis reveals vulnerabilities and opportunities invisible to those focused only on their immediate competitive environment.

The Kodak Tragedy: Seeing the Future and Missing the Point

Kodak invented the digital camera in 1975. Their technologists accurately predicted digital imaging would eventually dominate. They had first-mover advantage on the most significant technological shift in their industry.

They failed anyway.

RED TEAMING: THE ART OF QUESTIONING THE STATUS QUO

A Lecture on Innovation Through Adversarial Thinking

By Lawrence Aronhime

OPENING PROVOCATION

Here's a question that should make you uncomfortable:

What if everything you believe about your product, your market, or your solution is wrong?

Not slightly off. Not in need of minor adjustments. Completely, fundamentally wrong.

Most people never ask this question. They can't afford to—psychologically, financially, or politically. But the innovators who change industries? They don't just ask it. They weaponize it.

That's what we're here to talk about today: Red Teaming—the systematic art of attacking your own assumptions before someone else does it for you.

WHERE DID THIS MADNESS COME FROM?

The Prussian War Game (1811)

Picture this: You're a Prussian military officer in the early 1800s. You've spent weeks developing what you believe is a brilliant battle plan. Then, your commander does something strange—he assigns another team to destroy your plan from the enemy's perspective.

This wasn't friendly feedback. This was organized intellectual combat.

They called it Kriegsspiel—war gaming. The red team's job was singular: identify every flaw, every blind spot, every assumption that would get soldiers killed in actual combat.

The goal wasn't to be nice. The goal was to survive.

From Battlefield to Boardroom

Over 200 years, this methodology migrated:

1800s → Prussian military strategy

1960s → CIA intelligence analysis

The goal wasn't to be nice. The goal was to survive.

From Battlefield to Boardroom

Over 200 years, this methodology migrated:

1800s → Prussian military strategy

1960s → CIA intelligence analysis

1990s → Corporate cybersecurity

2000s → Business strategy and competitive intelligence

2020s → AI safety and user experience design

The principle remained constant: Better to find your weaknesses yourself than have your enemy—or your market—find them for you.

WHY BRAINSTORMING FAILS (AND WHY RED TEAMING WINS)

Let me challenge your thinking about innovation.

Traditional brainstorming has a fatal flaw: It optimizes for agreement, not truth.

Think about the last brainstorming session you attended:

Someone proposed an idea

Others built on it enthusiastically

The group converged on a "brilliant" solution

Everyone left feeling productive

What didn't happen? Someone systematically trying to destroy the idea to see if it could survive.

This is called confirmation bias at scale. Groups naturally reinforce existing thinking rather than challenge it.

The Red Teaming Alternative

Red Teaming flips this completely:

Instead of asking: "How can we make this work?"

We ask: "How can this fail spectacularly?"

Instead of: "What do users want?"

We ask: "What assumptions about users are we making that could be completely wrong?"

Instead of: "How do we improve our product?"

We ask: "How would a competitor destroy our entire business model?"

This is not pessimism. This is rigorous thinking.

THE THREE CORE PRINCIPLES OF RED TEAMING

PRINCIPLE 1: Think Like an Adversary

An adversary doesn't see your product the way you do. They see:

Vulnerabilities you're blind to

Assumptions you take for granted

Opportunities you're missing because you're too close

Example: The Smartphone

You think: "Our phone has great features, excellent design, premium materials."

An adversary thinks:

"What frustrates users most about needing to carry this device?"

"What technology could make smartphones obsolete?"

"How do users actually use this vs. how the company thinks they use it?"

This is how Tesla questioned whether cars needed gasoline. This is how Netflix questioned whether entertainment needed physical media. This is how SpaceX questioned whether rockets needed to be disposable.

PRINCIPLE 2: Attack Paradigms, Not Just Products

The biggest breakthroughs come from challenging fundamental assumptions about how an industry works.

Consider Kodak:

Their thinking: "We're the best at film photography"

The paradigm they missed: "Do people need film at all?"

Consider Netflix vs. Blockbuster:

Blockbuster's thinking: "We need better retail locations"

Red teaming forces you to ask:

What products/services maintain the current status quo?

PRINCIPLE 3: User-Centered Adversarial Thinking

This is where innovation happens: viewing your solution through the eyes of someone actively trying to break it OR through the eyes of a user experiencing it for the first time.

Questions to ask:

What happens when users behave in ways we didn't anticipate?

What systemic biases might create unintended outcomes for different user groups?

How would someone with malicious intent exploit this system?

What if users' stated preferences are different from their actual behaviors?

What assumptions do they rest on?

What would threaten the current system?

Knowledge transfer happens through lectures

1. The Devil's Advocate (Institutionalized)

The Catholic Church used a Advocatus Diaboli to argue against sainthood candidates. Why? To ensure they examined every flaw before making an irreversible decision.

Cybersecurity principle: Don't ask "Can we be hacked?" Ask "When we're hacked, what happens?"

Your version: Don't ask "Will this work?" Ask "When this fails, what breaks?"

3. The Prussian Question

After every battle, Prussian officers asked: "What did we think would happen, and what actually happened?"

Your version: After every project, ask: "What assumptions did we make, and which were wrong?"

COMMON MISTAKES (AND HOW TO AVOID THEM)

MISTAKE 1: Red Teaming Once

The Problem: Treating red teaming as a one-time check box

The Solution: Institutionalize it. Make it part of your process for every major decision.

Example: SpaceX doesn't just test rockets once. Every launch includes systematic failure analysis that feeds into the next design.

MISTAKE 2: Being Too Nice

The Problem: Pulling punches because you don't want to hurt feelings or kill momentum

The Solution: Remember—it's better for ideas to die in the conference room than in the market.

Example: Military red teams are graded on how thoroughly they attack plans. Adopt the same standard.

MISTAKE 3: Red Teaming Without Action

The Problem: Identifying vulnerabilities but not fixing them

The Solution: Every red team finding requires a response: fix it, accept the risk, or pivot.

The Solution: Red teaming is structured. Use frameworks (Beautiful Questions, Trending to the Absurd, Scenario Analysis).

The Problem: Limiting red teaming to cybersecurity when it applies to everything

The Solution: Apply it to business models, user experience, strategy, product design, everything.

THE ULTIMATE RED TEAMING QUESTION

Here's the question that separates good innovators from great ones:

"What would it take for everything we know to be wrong?"

Not "slightly off." Not "needs adjustment."

Fundamentally, completely, catastrophically wrong.

Most people can't ask this question. It's too threatening.

Why? They couldn't imagine their core assumptions being wrong.

Red teaming forces you to imagine it. And once you can imagine it, you can prepare for it. Or better yet—you can cause it and own the disruption yourself.

1983: Historian Thomas Hughes publishes "Networks of Power: Electrification in Western Society"

Everyone else studied electricity as invention history: Edison, Tesla, generators, light bulbs.

Hughes saw it as systems evolution: How technical components, economic incentives, regulatory frameworks, and social adaptations co-evolved across multiple levels.

His breakthrough: He identified that systems don't evolve uniformly. Some components race ahead. Others lag behind—creating "reverse salients".

Military metaphor: In warfare, a "salient" is a bulge forward in the battle line. A "reverse salient" is the opposite—the part of your line that's falling behind, creating vulnerability.

Innovation metaphor: The component that's holding the entire system back, creating a bottleneck where innovation pressure builds.

Why this matters: Where you find reverse salients, you find the highest-return innovation opportunities.

Success Story: The Electric Grid's Hidden Bottleneck

Early 1900s: Electric power is spreading rapidly.

Component level: Generators improving ✓

Production level: Power plants proliferating ✓

Distribution level: Wiring houses proceeding ✓

Device level: Electric appliances emerging ✓

But one level was lagging: Transmission infrastructure

Power plants were local. No way to transmit electricity long distances. Each city needed its own power plants. Inefficient. Expensive.

The reverse salient: Long-distance power transmission

Cautionary Tale: Why Google Glass Failed

2012: Google announces Glass—augmented reality headwear

Technology level: AR works, camera works, display works ✓

Design level: Wearable form factor achieved ✓

Software level: Apps and interfaces functional ✓

But other levels weren't ready:

Social level: Wearing cameras on your face = "glasshole" stigma ✗

Legal level: Privacy concerns, banned in many establishments ✗

Economic level: $1,500 price point for unclear value proposition ✗

Use case level: Solution searching for problem ✗

What went wrong: Google optimized the technology level while ignoring that the social, legal, and economic levels were reverse salients blocking adoption.

Contrast with AirPods (2016):

Social level: Wireless earbuds already normalized ✓

Economic level: $159 reasonable for audio quality ✓

Use case level: Clear value proposition (wire-free listening) ✓

COMMON MISTAKES TO AVOID

MISTAKE 1: Treating Hierarchy as Static Structure

Problem: Creating a map and treating it as fixed

Reality: Systems are dynamic. Levels evolve at different speeds. Structure shifts over time.

Fix: Annotate your map with:

Speed of change at each level

Direction of evolution

Emerging structures

Declining structures

MISTAKE 2: Missing Cross-Level Interactions

Problem: Seeing only containment (nested structure) but not interactions

Reality: Most interesting system dynamics come from how levels influence each other bidirectionally.

Fix: Explicitly map:

Feedback loops between levels

Constraints (higher level limits lower level)

Enablement (lower level enables higher level)

Emergence (lower level interaction creates higher level phenomena)

MISTAKE 3: Assuming Linear Causation

Problem: Thinking "fix component X → system improves"

MISTAKE 3: Assuming Linear Causation

Problem: Thinking "fix component X → system improves"

Reality: Complex systems have non-linear responses. Small changes can cascade dramatically. Big changes might be absorbed without effect.

Fix: Always map cascade effects before assuming impact.

MISTAKE 4: Optimizing Wrong Level

Problem: Solving problems at the level where they manifest rather than where they originate

Reality: Visible problems are often symptoms of constraints at other levels.

Fix: When stuck, move up or down a level and see if the intervention point changes.

MISTAKE 5: Ignoring Timing and Readiness

Problem: Identifying opportunities without assessing if system is ready

Reality: Great ideas fail when other levels aren't prepared to support them.

Fix: Always complete enabling/constraining factor analysis. Don't pursue opportunities where too many levels block adoption.

Opening with Impact:

Start with a specific, uncomfortable question—not a generic statement. Examples:

COMMON STUDENT CHALLENGES

Challenge 1: Picking the Obvious Constraint

Symptom: Students identify what everyone in the industry already knows as the constraint.

Cause: Staying at surface level, not pushing past conventional wisdom.

Solution:

Ask: "If everyone knows this is the constraint, why hasn't it been solved?"

Push: "What second-order constraint might emerge if this were solved?"

Challenge: "What would someone who disagrees with you say?"

Challenge 2: Confusing Symptoms with Constraints

Symptom: Students identify consequences rather than causes.

Cause: Insufficient root cause analysis.

Solution:

Apply "5 Whys" rigorously

Ask: "Why does that happen?" until you hit bedrock

Distinguish: "Is this a cause or an effect?"

Challenge 3: Assuming Technical Solutions

Symptom: All proposed problems are framed as technology challenges.

Cause: Engineering bias, comfort with technical framing.

Solution:

Require problem framings across all constraint types

Ask: "What if technology wasn't the answer?"

Show examples where non-technical solutions addressed technical-seeming constraints

FINAL NOTES

The Core Insight to Convey

The fundamental teaching point of Reverse Salient is this:

Innovation effort is scarce. Direct it where it will have maximum impact—the constraint that holds everything else back.

This simple idea has profound implications:

Don't improve what's already good enough

Don't work on exciting problems that don't matter

Find what's blocking progress, define it precisely, solve it

The Hughes Quote to Remember

"Defining reverse salient problems is the essence of the creative process."

This inverts the usual assumption about creativity. Creativity isn't brainstorming wild ideas—it's identifying exactly where the system is stuck and what it would take to unstick it.

Students who master this material should leave with:

A systematic method for finding high-impact problems

The discipline to resist scattered effort

HISTORICAL CONTEXT: THE CASE FOR REVERSE SALIENT ANALYSIS

Success Story: The Battle of the Currents

In the 1880s, Thomas Edison built the first practical electrical system—but it had a fatal flaw. Direct current couldn't economically transmit more than about one mile from the power station. Edison's team threw tremendous resources at this problem, trying to extend transmission distance through better conductors, higher voltages, and thicker wires.

They failed. The constraint was fundamental to DC architecture.

Meanwhile, George Westinghouse and Nikola Tesla recognized this constraint differently. Rather than trying to solve it within the DC system, they asked: "What would a system without this constraint look like?"

The answer was alternating current, which could use transformers to step voltage up for efficient transmission and down for safe use. AC didn't improve on DC's reverse salient—it eliminated it by changing the architecture.

The lesson: Correctly identifying the reverse salient is half the battle. Understanding its nature—whether it's solvable within the current system or signals the need for a new paradigm—is the other half.

Cautionary Tale: Kodak's Digital Dilemma

In 1975, Steven Sasson at Kodak invented the digital camera. Kodak correctly identified that image quality was a reverse salient—early digital couldn't match film. They invested heavily in improving digital image sensors.

But Kodak made a critical error in their reverse salient analysis. They focused on the technical constraint (image quality) while ignoring the business model constraint. Their entire profit structure depended on film and photo processing revenue. Even as digital image quality improved, they couldn't address the economic reverse salient without cannibalizing their core business.

Competitors without film legacy could address the digital opportunity without this constraint. By the time Kodak adjusted, it was too late.

The lesson: Reverse salients aren't always technical. Economic structures, business models, organizational capabilities, and industry arrangements can all be binding constraints. The most dangerous reverse salients are the ones you don't see because they're embedded in your own assumptions.

Mistake 1: Confusing Symptoms with Constraints

Problem: Identifying surface-level issues rather than binding constraints.

Fix: Apply the blocking test rigorously. Ask "If we solved this tomorrow, would the system truly advance?"

Mistake 2: Picking the Obvious Problem

Problem: Everyone knows batteries are the constraint, so that's where you focus—along with everyone else.

Fix: Look for second-order constraints or less obvious approaches to the primary constraint.

REVERSE SALIENT: Finding the Bottleneck That Holds Everything Back

A Lecture on Identifying Where Concentrated Innovation Effort Can Transform Entire Systems

By Lawrence Aronhime

OPENING PROVOCATION

Here's a question that separates those who actually change the world from those who just tinker at the margins:

Why do most innovation efforts fail to move the needle—even when the technology works, the team is talented, and the market exists?

The answer isn't "poor execution" or "bad timing"—those are symptoms, not causes.

The answer is: They're solving the wrong problem. They're innovating in parts of the system that aren't holding anything back.

Think about it: In any complex technological or business system, some components advance rapidly while others lag behind. The lagging components—the reverse salients—are where the real opportunity lives. Because they're the reason the whole system can't progress.

Edison perfected the lightbulb, but it was meaningless without a power distribution system. The smartphone was technically possible years before the iPhone, but batteries couldn't support it. Electric vehicles sat on drawing boards for decades waiting for one thing: battery energy density.

Most innovators pick their problems based on what's exciting or what they know how to do. The best innovators pick problems based on what's actually holding the system back.

Most innovators pick their problems based on what's exciting or what they know how to do. The best innovators pick problems based on what's actually holding the system back.

This is Reverse Salient Analysis—the systematic identification of components that lag behind in system development, representing not just bottlenecks, but concentrated opportunities for outsized impact.

Thomas Hughes, studying the electrification of Western society, coined this term from military strategy. A "salient" is a forward-projecting part of a battle line. A "reverse salient" is the part that falls behind and becomes vulnerable—the weak point that the entire force must protect or correct before advancing.

In technology and innovation, reverse salients are the components that hold back everything else. Find them, solve them, and you unlock the entire system.

THE PROBLEM WITH CONVENTIONAL INNOVATION TARGETING

Let me tell you why most innovation programs produce incremental improvements instead of breakthroughs:

They spray effort across the entire system instead of concentrating it where it matters.

Imagine a company trying to improve its supply chain. They hire consultants who recommend fifty initiatives across warehousing, transportation, inventory management, supplier relationships, and demand forecasting. Resources get spread thin. Progress happens everywhere—and nowhere.

What they should have done: Find the reverse salient. Which specific component is preventing the entire supply chain from reaching the next level of performance? Maybe it's real-time visibility across handoff points. Maybe it's the inflexibility of contracted transportation capacity. Maybe it's the 72-hour lag in demand signal propagation.

There's always a constraint that matters more than the others. Systems theory tells us this. Eliyahu Goldratt built an entire management philosophy (Theory of Constraints) around it. But most organizations lack a systematic method for identifying what that constraint actually is—especially in complex technological domains where the bottleneck isn't obvious.

Consider the history of electric power. In the 1880s, multiple inventors worked on improving every aspect of electrical systems—generators, motors, transmission lines, insulators, switches. But Thomas Hughes's meticulous research revealed something crucial: progress came in waves, each triggered by solving a specific reverse salient.

The first wave came from solving the lightbulb filament problem. Then the reverse salient shifted to reliable generators. Then to transmission distance—direct current couldn't economically travel more than a few miles from the power station. This reverse salient couldn't be solved within the DC paradigm, so an entirely new system (alternating current) emerged to address it. Then AC had its own reverse salient: the lack of a practical AC motor.

Each breakthrough came from concentrated attention on the lagging component. Not from general improvement across all fronts.

This is why reverse salient analysis matters: it tells you where to focus. In a world of limited resources and infinite possibilities, knowing where concentrated effort will have maximum impact is perhaps the most valuable strategic insight you can have.

WHERE THIS THINKING COMES FROM

Thomas Hughes and the Electrification of the West

Thomas P. Hughes was a historian of technology at the University of Pennsylvania who spent decades studying how large technological systems evolve. His masterwork, Networks of Power: Electrification in Western Society, 1880-1930 (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1983), remains one of the most influential studies of technological change ever written.

Hughes borrowed the term "salient" from military strategy. In warfare, a salient is a portion of a battle line that projects forward toward the enemy—an aggressive advance. A reverse salient is the opposite: a portion that lags behind, creating a vulnerable indentation in the line that must be corrected before the whole force can advance.

Hughes applied this concept to technological systems with devastating precision:

"A reverse salient appears in an expanding system when a component of the system does not march along harmoniously with other components. As the system evolves toward a goal, some components fall behind or out of line. As a result of the reverse salient, growth of the entire enterprise is hampered, or thwarted, and thus remedial action is required."

What made Hughes's insight powerful was his observation about what happens next:

"Having identified the reverse salients, the system tenders can then analyze them as a series of critical problems. Defining reverse salient problems is the essence of the creative process."

This is a profound claim: creativity in technological innovation isn't about generating wild ideas—it's about correctly identifying where the system is stuck and precisely defining the critical problems that, if solved, would unstick it.

The Military Origins

The metaphor is worth understanding deeply. In trench warfare, an uneven battle line creates strategic problems. The portions that advance (salients) become vulnerable to flanking attacks. The portions that fall behind (reverse salients) become pressure points where the enemy can concentrate force.

Commanders face a choice: they can continue advancing the strong points and hope the weak points catch up, or they can concentrate resources on the reverse salient to bring the whole line forward.

In technological systems, the same dynamic plays out. Some components advance rapidly due to investment, talent, or favorable physics. Others lag behind. And until the lagging components catch up, the entire system is constrained to the capability of its weakest link.

From History to Innovation Methodology

Hughes's historical insight has become a practical innovation methodology because it answers a question every innovator faces: Where should I focus?

The answer: Focus on the reverse salient—the lagging component that, if advanced, would allow the entire system to progress. This is where:

Resources can have maximum impact

Problems are concrete and defined (not vague)

Success can be clearly measured

Solutions have guaranteed demand (the system needs them)

THE REVERSE SALIENT FRAMEWORK

What We Mean By "Reverse Salient"

A reverse salient is not merely a weak point or an area for improvement. It's specifically:

A component of a technological or business system that has fallen behind other components in a way that prevents the overall system from advancing toward its goals.

Key characteristics:

System Dependency: The lagging component is interconnected with other components such that its underperformance limits them all

Clear Metrics: You can measure what "falling behind" means—efficiency, cost, reliability, speed, or other performance dimensions

Blocking Progress: If the reverse salient were corrected, the entire system could advance; without correction, further improvements elsewhere have diminishing returns

Identifiable Causes: The reverse salient exists for reasons that can be analyzed—physical limits, economic constraints, regulatory barriers, or knowledge gaps

The Three Core Principles

Principle 1: Every System Has a Reverse Salient

Complex systems never advance uniformly. Some components will always lag. The question isn't whether reverse salients exist—they always do—but whether you've correctly identified them.

Complex systems never advance uniformly. Some components will always lag. The question isn't whether reverse salients exist—they always do—but whether you've correctly identified them.

Sometimes the reverse salient is obvious (everyone in the industry knows batteries are the problem). Sometimes it's hidden (the real bottleneck is software architecture, but everyone is focused on hardware). Often it shifts over time (you solve one reverse salient only to reveal the next one).

Principle 2: Reverse Salients Evolve in Sequence

Hughes observed that solving one reverse salient often reveals or creates the next. The history of electric power shows this clearly:

Edison solved the filament problem → revealed generator reliability as next reverse salient

Reliable generators → revealed transmission distance as next reverse salient

AC power solved transmission → revealed lack of practical AC motor as next reverse salient

Polyphase motor invented → revealed safety and insulation problems as next reverse salient

This sequential nature means reverse salient analysis isn't a one-time exercise. It's a continuous discipline of reassessing where the new constraint lies.

Principle 3: Correction Can Be Within or Beyond the System

When engineers identify a reverse salient, they attempt to solve it within the existing system architecture. But sometimes this proves impossible.

ple 3: Correction Can Be Within or Beyond the System

When engineers identify a reverse salient, they attempt to solve it within the existing system architecture. But sometimes this proves impossible.

Direct current couldn't economically transmit beyond a few miles—this was a fundamental physical limit, not an engineering challenge waiting for a better solution. The answer came from outside the DC system: alternating current, which could use transformers to step voltage up for transmission and down for use.

This principle is crucial: not every reverse salient can be solved within its original context. Sometimes the answer is to build an entirely new system that doesn't have the constraint in the first place.

The Mechanism: Why This Works

Reverse salient analysis works because it aligns innovation effort with system demand.

When you solve a reverse salient:

Guaranteed Market: The rest of the system is waiting for this problem to be solved. Demand is proven by the very existence of the bottleneck.

Clear Specification: The problem is defined by what the rest of the system needs from this component. Requirements aren't vague—they're set by the interface with adjacent components.

Measurable Success: You know when you've succeeded because the constraint relaxes and the system can advance.

Compound Value: Your solution doesn't just improve one component—it unlocks value across the entire system.

WHY REVERSE SALIENT ANALYSIS MATTERS FOR INNOVATION

Reason 1: It Converts Vague Opportunity into Defined Problem

The hardest part of innovation isn't solving problems—it's knowing which problems to solve.

Most innovation programs start with vague directions: "improve customer experience," "reduce costs," "increase speed." These aren't problems; they're wishes. They don't tell you what to do, how to know when you're done, or why your solution will matter.

Reverse salient analysis converts wish into specification:

Instead of: "Improve electric vehicle adoption"

Reverse salient: "Battery energy density limits range to 200 miles, below the 300-mile psychological threshold where mainstream consumers overcome range anxiety"

Problem specification: "Increase battery energy density by 50% at equivalent cost and safety"

Now you know exactly what success looks like, what physics you're fighting, and why achieving it would unlock the larger goal.

Reason 2: It Prioritizes Maximum-Impact Opportunities

Reason 2: It Prioritizes Maximum-Impact Opportunities

Innovation resources—talent, capital, time—are always scarce relative to opportunities. You can't pursue everything. How do you choose?

Most organizations prioritize based on:

What leadership is excited about

What competitors are doing

What's technically feasible with current capabilities

What has the largest addressable market

These criteria often lead to crowded spaces with incremental improvements.

Reverse salient analysis provides a different prioritization lens: What problem, if solved, would have the most cascading impact on the system?

This often points to less-obvious opportunities—the hard problems that others have avoided, but which would unlock massive value if cracked.

Reason 3: It Identifies Timing

Technology timing is notoriously difficult. Too early and you burn resources waiting for the market. Too late and you're fighting established players.

Reverse salients provide timing signals:

The reverse salient is being attacked by many players → Market timing may be right, but competition will be fierce

The reverse salient is recognized but few are working on it → Either it's truly hard, or there's a hidden opportunity

The reverse salient isn't widely recognized → You may be early, but you could also be seeing something others miss

Reason 4: It Reveals When Paradigm Shifts Are Coming

Sometimes reverse salients can't be solved within the existing system architecture. This signals something important: the system may be approaching its limits, and a new paradigm may be emerging.

Direct current's transmission limitation couldn't be solved with DC technology. The reverse salient was fundamental, not incremental. This fundamental limit created the opening for AC power to emerge.

When you encounter a reverse salient that resists all conventional solutions, ask: What would a completely different system architecture look like? This is often where paradigm-shifting innovations originate.

CASE STUDIES

Case Study 1: The Electrification of America (DC vs. AC)

The Challenge: In the 1880s, Thomas Edison had built a working electrical system around direct current. Central power stations generated DC power, which was distributed to nearby homes and businesses for lighting. The technology worked—but it couldn't scale.

Identifying the Reverse Salient: The DC system had a fundamental constraint: economical transmission distance. DC couldn't be stepped up to high voltage for efficient transmission, so power stations had to be within about one mile of customers. This meant every neighborhood needed its own power station—economically impossible for anything but dense urban areas.

Attempted Solutions Within the System: Edison and his engineers tried everything to extend DC transmission range. Better conductors. Higher voltages (dangerous). Thicker wires (expensive). Nothing worked. The physics of DC power transmission set a hard limit.

eers tried everything to extend DC transmission range. Better conductors. Higher voltages (dangerous). Thicker wires (expensive). Nothing worked. The physics of DC power transmission set a hard limit.

The Paradigm Shift: Because the reverse salient couldn't be solved within the DC architecture, inventors explored an entirely different approach: alternating current. AC power could use transformers to step voltage up for efficient transmission and down for safe use. This architectural change completely eliminated the transmission distance constraint.

Key Insight: When AC emerged, Edison famously fought it (the "War of Currents"). But the reverse salient didn't care about Edison's preference. The DC system's constraint was fundamental, and AC offered a path around it.

Why This Is Important: Reverse salient analysis revealed not just a problem to solve, but a limit of the existing paradigm. This pattern repeats across innovation history: when a reverse salient proves fundamentally unsolvable within the current architecture, the opening exists for an entirely new approach.

Case Study 2: The Shale Revolution

The Challenge: The United States had vast reserves of oil and natural gas trapped in shale rock formations. The resource was known—but conventional drilling couldn't extract it economically.

The Challenge: The United States had vast reserves of oil and natural gas trapped in shale rock formations. The resource was known—but conventional drilling couldn't extract it economically.

Identifying the Reverse Salient: Shale is impermeable. Unlike conventional reservoirs where oil flows to the well, shale locks hydrocarbons in place. The reverse salient wasn't the existence of oil (proved) or the ability to drill (mastered)—it was extraction from impermeable rock.

A Sequence of Reverse Salients: The shale revolution illustrates how solving one reverse salient reveals the next:

First Reverse Salient: Shale impermeability → Solution: Hydraulic fracturing (creating artificial fractures in rock)

Second Reverse Salient: Shallow shale deposits meant limited reserves per well → Solution: Horizontal drilling (dramatically expanding each well's reach)

Third Reverse Salient: Oil molecules larger than gas couldn't flow through fractures → Solution: Modified fracking fluid formulations

Fourth Reverse Salient: High R&D costs with uncertain returns → Solution: Small independent operators willing to take risks, learning from each other's experiments

Key Insight: The shale revolution wasn't one breakthrough—it was systematic identification and correction of sequential reverse salients. Each solution enabled the next problem to become visible and addressable.

Case Study 3: DNA Data Storage

The Challenge: Digital data is growing exponentially, overwhelming traditional storage technologies. DNA offers theoretical storage density millions of times greater than magnetic media—a single gram could store all human knowledge ever created.

Mapping the Reverse Salients: Unlike mature technologies, DNA storage has multiple severe reverse salients:

Synthesis Costs: Writing data into DNA costs roughly $3,500 per megabyte—about 10 million times more expensive than conventional storage

Encoding/Decoding Speed: Current synthesis and sequencing technologies make read/write speeds impractically slow

Random Access: DNA storage lacks efficient random access—you can't jump to a specific data segment easily

NESTED HIERARCHIES: Seeing the System Behind the Problem

A Lecture on Systems Understanding and Innovation Opportunity Discovery

By Lawrence Aronhime

OPENING PROVOCATION

Here's a question that should fundamentally change how you approach innovation:

Why did fixing the battery problem require solving the transmission problem first?

Think about that for a moment. In the 1880s, Thomas Edison had created something remarkable—a functioning electric light system. The problem? It only worked within a few hundred yards of the power station. The batteries that stored electricity couldn't hold enough charge to make the system economically viable at scale.

The obvious answer is "because batteries weren't good enough." But that's not the real answer—that's the surface answer, and surface answers are the enemy of innovation.

The real answer is: batteries exist within a system of nested hierarchies, and you cannot fix a component without understanding its position within the larger system architecture.

The real answer is: batteries exist within a system of nested hierarchies, and you cannot fix a component without understanding its position within the larger system architecture.

Edison's batteries were fine for their immediate purpose. The problem was that direct current couldn't be transmitted efficiently over long distances. No matter how good you made the battery, you were constrained by a limitation at a higher level of the system hierarchy—the transmission infrastructure. The solution didn't come from building better batteries; it came from changing the system entirely—from direct current to alternating current—which then made different battery designs possible and necessary.

Most innovators miss this. They see a problem in a component and attack that component directly. They spend millions improving batteries when the constraint is in transmission. They redesign user interfaces when the friction is in the business model. They hire better salespeople when the product architecture is fundamentally misaligned with customer needs.

This is Nested Hierarchies—the systematic method for understanding that every element exists within a system, every system exists within a larger system, and innovation opportunities often lie not in fixing the obvious component, but in understanding how changes at one level cascade through all the others.

THE PROBLEM WITH COMPONENT-LEVEL THINKING

Let me tell you why most innovation efforts fail to produce breakthrough results:

They focus on parts when they should focus on patterns.

Specifically, the motor that drives insulin delivery fails after approximately 18 months of continuous use. The engineering team springs into action. They analyze the motor design, test different materials, consult with motor specialists. After two years and $15 million in R&D, they've extended motor life to 24 months.

They've improved the motor by 33%—and completely missed the opportunity.

Level 1: The Motor Component

The motor drives the pump mechanism

Motor reliability affects delivery accuracy

The pump contains motor, reservoir, electronics, interface

Device design determines user interaction patterns

System integration determines treatment effectiveness

Most problem-solving methodologies—root cause analysis, design thinking, lean improvement—operate at the component level. WHERE THIS THINKING COMES FROM

The intellectual foundation for nested hierarchies in innovation comes from three converging streams of thought, each revealing something essential about how complex systems actually work.

Herbert Simon and the Architecture of Complexity

Herbert Simon, the Nobel laureate who gave us bounded rationality and satisficing, also gave us one of the most powerful insights about complex systems. In his landmark essay "The Architecture of Complexity" (1962), Simon argued that all complex systems are hierarchically organized.

Simon's famous parable of the two watchmakers illustrates why:

content:
tems. In his landmark essay "The Architecture of Complexity" (1962), Simon argued that all complex systems are hierarchically organized.

Simon's famous parable of the two watchmakers illustrates why:

Imagine two watchmakers, Hora and Tempus, who made equally fine watches. Each watch contained about 1,000 parts. Tempus constructed his watches so that if he had to put one down—to answer the phone, say—it immediately fell to pieces and had to be reassembled from scratch. Hora designed his watches so that he could put together subassemblies of about ten elements each. Ten of these subassemblies constituted a larger subassembly; ten of these formed the whole watch.

If there is a probability of one in ten that either watchmaker will be interrupted while adding a part, Hora will be interrupted on average 9 times while completing a watch. Tempus, on the other hand, will have to start over, on average, 10 times for every watch he assembles—he will never complete one.

Simon's point was profound: Hierarchical organization isn't just one way to structure complexity—it's the only way complex systems can evolve and persist. Any system that lacks hierarchical organization will be inherently fragile and unable to survive perturbations.

For innovation, this means: Understanding the hierarchical structure of a system tells you where it is robust (perturbations are absorbed within a level) and where it is fragile (perturbations cascade across levels). Innovation opportunities concentrate at the boundaries between levels.

Thomas Hughes and Technological Systems

Thomas Hughes, the historian of technology whose masterwork "Networks of Power" (1983) traced the evolution of electrical systems from 1880 to 1930, provided the empirical grounding for systems thinking in innovation.

Hughes showed that technological systems are not just collections of hardware. They are seamlessly interrelated physical, intellectual, and organizational components that evolve together. The electric power system wasn't just generators and wires—it was Edison and Westinghouse, corporate organizations, regulatory bodies, financial markets, consumer expectations, and cultural assumptions about progress.

Most importantly, Hughes introduced the concept of reverse salients—components or aspects of a system that have fallen behind or are out of phase with the others. The direct current transmission problem was a reverse salient: it constrained the entire system's growth regardless of improvements elsewhere.

For innovation, Hughes revealed that the most consequential innovations address reverse salients—the constraints that hold back entire system hierarchies. Finding these reverse salients requires seeing the whole hierarchy, not just the components.

Donella Meadows and Leverage Points

Donella Meadows, the systems scientist whose "Thinking in Systems" became the essential primer for systems thinking, showed us that not all interventions in a system are equal.

Meadows identified a hierarchy of intervention points in systems, ranging from the easiest but least effective (changing parameters like prices or subsidies) to the hardest but most powerful (changing the goals or paradigm of the system). Her insight was that most people focus on the easy interventions that have minimal impact, while transformative change requires intervening at deeper structural levels.

THE NESTED HIERARCHIES FRAMEWORK

What We Mean by Nested Hierarchies

A nested hierarchy is a system structure in which each level is contained within a larger level and contains smaller levels within itself. Like Russian nesting dolls, each layer exists simultaneously as a whole system at its own level and as a component of the larger system above it.

This is not just a metaphor—it's an architectural reality of virtually every domain worth innovating in:

Biological Systems:

Molecules → Organelles → Cells → Tissues → Organs → Organ Systems → Organisms → Populations → Ecosystems

Technological Systems:

Components → Modules → Subsystems → Systems → Platforms → Infrastructures → Technological Regimes

Social Systems:

Individuals → Teams → Departments → Organizations → Industries → Economies → Societies

Information Systems:

Bits → Bytes → Files → Applications → Operating Systems → Networks → The Internet → Digital Civilization

The key insight is that each level has its own logic, constraints, and dynamics—but these are always shaped by and shape the levels above and below.

The Five Core Principles

Principle 1: Containment Defines Constraint

A component at any level is constrained by the system that contains it. No matter how good you make a battery, if the transmission infrastructure requires direct current at short distances, the battery's potential is limited by that higher-level constraint.

Innovation Implication: Before optimizing a component, identify what higher-level constraints are limiting its effectiveness. The opportunity may be in changing the constraint, not improving the component.

Principle 2: Change Cascades in Both Directions

Changes at any level propagate both upward (affecting the containing system) and downward (affecting contained components). When alternating current replaced direct current, it changed requirements for motors, insulation, safety systems, business models, and regulatory frameworks.

Innovation Implication: Map the cascade effects of any contemplated change. The most valuable innovations create positive cascades across multiple levels.

Principle 3: Boundaries Are Where Innovation Lives

The interfaces between levels—where one hierarchy meets another—are where the most significant innovation opportunities exist. These boundaries are often poorly defined, creating friction that can be eliminated or exploited.

Principle 4: Reverse Salients Signal Opportunity

When one element of a system lags behind others in its development or performance, it creates a reverse salient—a constraint that limits the entire system. These reverse salients are high-value innovation targets.

The purpose or goal of the containing system determines what performance characteristics matter for its components. A motor designed for reliability in an industrial setting has different requirements than one designed for miniaturization in a medical device.

Innovation Implication: Always understand the purpose of the containing system before optimizing a component. Optimization without system purpose alignment is waste.

Key Concepts and Terminology

System: An interconnected set of elements coherently organized to achieve something. A system has elements, interconnections, and a function or purpose.

Hierarchy Level: A distinct stratum in the nested structure where elements at that level share similar characteristics, constraints, and dynamics.

Boundary: The interface between levels where information, materials, or energy flow from one level to another.

Reverse Salient: A component or aspect of a system that has fallen behind or is out of phase with others, constraining the system's overall development.

Leverage Point: A place in a system where a small shift can produce large changes throughout the system hierarchy.

System Purpose: The goal or function that the system is organized to achieve, which determines what counts as "performance" for its components.

Cascade Effect: The propagation of changes at one level to other levels, either upward (affecting containing systems) or downward (affecting contained systems).

THE NESTED HIERARCHIES METHOD: SIX STEPS

The Nested Hierarchies method translates systems thinking into actionable innovation analysis. These six steps take you from selecting a domain to generating a prioritized list of innovation opportunities.

STEP 1: Select Domain and Define Central Element

Objective: Establish the focal point for your analysis

The first step is selecting a domain that interests you and identifying the central element you want to analyze. The central element is typically a product, technology, process, or service that you want to understand in its systemic context.

Actions:

Choose a domain where you suspect innovation opportunities exist

Identify the specific element that will serve as your analytical anchor

Define what "performance" means for this element

Articulate why this element matters to you or your organization

Questions to Ask:

What element in this domain feels like it's "stuck" or advancing slowly?

What element do I have access to improve?

What element do customers complain about most frequently?

Case Study 1: The Electrification of Western Society

The Challenge:

In the 1880s, multiple inventors and entrepreneurs were racing to create practical electric lighting. Thomas Edison had created a working incandescent bulb and a direct current (DC) power system that could illuminate a small area of lower Manhattan. But scaling the system beyond a few city blocks seemed impossible—the economics simply didn't work.

The Hierarchy:

Level +3: Economic System → Industrial growth, urbanization, demand for productivity

Level +2: Energy Infrastructure → Gas lighting, coal power, early electrical experiments

Level +1: Power Distribution → Generation, transmission, distribution networks

Level 0: Electric Lighting System → Bulbs, wiring, meters, switches

Level -1: Core Components → Filaments, glass envelopes, generators, conductors

Level -2: Materials/Chemistry → Carbon, tungsten, copper, insulation materials

The Reverse Salient:

The Reverse Salient:

Edison's engineers initially focused on the bulb (Level 0) and its components (Level -1). But the real reverse salient was at Level +1—transmission infrastructure. Direct current couldn't be transmitted economically over long distances. No matter how efficient you made the bulbs or generators, the system was constrained by transmission economics.

The Innovation:

Nikola Tesla and George Westinghouse identified that the constraint wasn't in the components but in the system architecture. Alternating current, which could be easily transformed to higher voltages for efficient long-distance transmission and then stepped down for safe local use, resolved the reverse salient.

But this wasn't just a technical fix—it required innovation at multiple levels:

Level -1: New motor designs (AC motors worked differently than DC)

Level 0: New safety systems (higher voltages required different insulation)

Level +1: New transmission infrastructure (transformers, different wiring)

Level +2: New business models (central station vs. distributed generation)

Level +3: New regulatory frameworks (safety standards, utility regulation)

Case Study 2: The Shale Revolution

The Challenge:

By 2000, U.S. oil production had been declining for three decades. The major oil companies had largely abandoned domestic exploration, focusing on international mega-projects. Vast shale formations were known to contain oil and gas, but the petroleum was locked in rock so impermeable that it couldn't flow to wells using conventional drilling.

The Hierarchy:

Level +2: U.S. Energy Industry → Majors, independents, refiners, distributors

Level +1: Oil & Gas Production System → Exploration, drilling, completion, production

Level 0: Shale Extraction → Horizontal drilling, hydraulic fracturing, production

Level -2: Materials/Chemistry → Fracking fluids, proppants, casing materials

The Reverse Salients (Sequential):

The shale revolution is a perfect example of identifying and resolving reverse salients sequentially:

Reverse Salient 1: Rock Impermeability Shale was known to contain hydrocarbons, but the rock was so tight that conventional drilling produced nothing. The innovation? Hydraulic fracturing—pumping fluid at high pressure to crack the rock and create pathways for oil and gas to flow.

Reverse Salient 2: Limited Well Access Even with fracking, each well only accessed a small vertical column of rock. The economics were marginal. The innovation? Horizontal drilling—drilling down to the shale layer, then turning the wellbore to run horizontally through the formation for thousands of feet.

Reverse Salient 3: Fracturing Fluid Chemistry Early fracking worked for natural gas but not for oil—the oil molecules were too large to pass through the fractures created for gas. The innovation? Modified fluid chemistry that created wider fracture networks.

Reverse Salient 4: Capital Intensity Each well required massive upfront investment with uncertain returns. The innovation? Financial engineering—pooling wells into portfolios, creating new securities, accessing capital markets.

Mental Model 1: Hierarchy as Strategy Space

Think of the nested hierarchy not just as a map of how things are, but as a map of where you could compete. At each level, different competitors exist, different capabilities matter, and different business models work.

The Strategic Question: At what level of the hierarchy should we compete?

Component suppliers compete at lower levels (Intel in CPUs)

Product companies compete at middle levels (Dell in computers)

Platform companies compete at boundaries between levels (Apple in ecosystems)

Infrastructure companies compete at high levels (Google in information organization)

Mental Model 2: Reverse Salient as Innovation Compass

Not all problems are equal. A reverse salient isn't just any problem—it's the rate-limiting step for the entire system. Solving a reverse salient has disproportionate value because it unlocks progress across multiple levels.

How to test if something is a reverse salient:

If this problem were solved, would the system advance significantly?

Is progress in other areas being held back by this problem?

Are multiple actors affected by this constraint, not just one?

Has this problem persisted despite significant investment in solving it?

If yes to all four, you've found a reverse salient worth attacking.

MISTAKE 1: Starting Too Low in the Hierarchy

The Problem: Analysts begin their mapping at the component level they know best and never adequately explore the containing systems above.

The Reality Check: The most consequential constraints are usually 2-3 levels above where you start looking. If you start at the component level and only go one level up, you miss the system dynamics that actually determine success.

The Fix: Always force yourself to map at least 3 levels above your central element. Even if the upper levels seem abstract, they shape everything below.

Example: An engineer improving battery energy density starts at chemistry (Level -2), maps up to battery design (Level -1), reaches device design (Level 0), but stops. They miss how charging infrastructure (Level +1), energy policy (Level +2), and urban design (Level +3) will determine whether any battery improvement actually matters.

MISTAKE 2: Treating Levels as Independent

The Problem: Analysts map the hierarchy but then analyze each level in isolation, missing the cascading interactions that create both opportunities and constraints.

The Reality Check: The whole point of nested hierarchies is understanding interdependence. An improvement at one level that creates problems at another level isn't an improvement at all.

The Fix: For every change you contemplate, explicitly trace its effects both upward and downward through at least 2-3 levels.

Example: A rideshare company reduces driver payments to improve unit economics (Level +1 financial constraint). But this cascades down (worse service quality at Level 0) and up (regulatory backlash at Level +2, labor organizing at Level +3). The "improvement" creates system instability.

MISTAKE 3: Confusing Components and Levels

The Problem: Analysts list many components within a single level but call them different levels. This creates a "hierarchy" that's actually just a parts list.

The Reality Check: Different levels have different organizing principles, different dynamics, and different stakeholders. If two things have the same organizing principle, they're probably at the same level.

The Fix: For each level, ask: "What is the system purpose at this level? Who are the actors? What are the rules?" If the answers are the same as the level above or below, you haven't actually identified a distinct level.

Example: Someone lists "motor, battery, controller, frame" as four levels of an electric scooter. But these are all components at the same level—they're all part of "the scooter product." The real levels are: subcomponents → scooter product → fleet operation → urban mobility → city system.

MISTAKE 4: Ignoring Non-Technical Levels

The Problem: Engineers and technologists map the technical hierarchy in great detail but ignore social, regulatory, and economic levels that often determine success.

The Reality Check: Most innovation failures aren't technical—they're market, regulatory, or social failures. The upper levels of the hierarchy are where these non-technical constraints live.

The Fix: Always include at least one level that is primarily social/cultural, one that is regulatory/institutional, and one that is economic/market. These are where most reverse salients hide.

Example: Nuclear fusion researchers map plasma physics, reactor design, and power systems in exquisite detail. But they underweight regulatory approval timelines (Level +2), grid integration challenges (Level +2), and public acceptance (Level +3) that have delayed deployment for decades.

MISTAKE 5: Finding Reverse Salients That Aren't Rate-Limiting

The Problem: Analysts identify problems and call them reverse salients when they're actually secondary constraints that wouldn't unlock progress even if solved.

The Reality Check: A reverse salient is specifically the binding constraint that limits system evolution. There's usually only one at a time—multiple constraints can exist, but only one is currently rate-limiting.

The Fix: For each proposed reverse salient, ask: "If we solved this tomorrow, would the system advance significantly?" If other constraints would immediately become binding, your proposed reverse salient isn't the true rate-limiting step.

Example: Someone identifies "user interface complexity" as the reverse salient for EV adoption. But solving UI wouldn't change adoption—the binding constraints are charging infrastructure and upfront cost. UI is a problem but not the reverse salient.

MISTAKE 6: Mapping Static Hierarchies

The Problem: Analysts create a snapshot of how the hierarchy exists today without considering how the hierarchy itself is evolving.

The Reality Check: Hierarchies are dynamic. Levels emerge and disappear. New actors enter at different levels. Boundaries shift. A static map misses the motion that creates the biggest opportunities.

The Fix: Create two hierarchy maps—one for today and one for your scenario horizon (5-10 years). Note where levels are consolidating, emerging, or shifting. The dynamics of hierarchy change often point to the best opportunities.

The Problem: Analysts create ever-more-detailed hierarchy maps, adding sublevels and sub-sublevels, without ever converging on actionable insights.

The Reality Check: The purpose of hierarchy mapping is to find leverage points and reverse salients, not to create comprehensive documentation of everything that exists.

The Fix: Set a time limit for mapping (2-4 hours max for initial analysis). After mapping, force prioritization: "What are the 3 most consequential reverse salients? What are the 3 highest-leverage intervention points?" Move to action rather than continued analysis.

Example: A team spends three months mapping the healthcare system in ever-increasing detail, cataloging every stakeholder and subsystem. But they never identify which reverse salient to target or where their capabilities could create leverage. The map is comprehensive and useless.

THE ULTIMATE NESTED HIERARCHIES QUESTION

Here is the question that separates system thinkers from component fixers:

"At what level of the system hierarchy does this problem actually live?"

This question is deceptively simple but transformationally powerful. It forces you to stop assuming that the obvious problem—the one that presents itself at the level where you operate—is actually the problem worth solving.

The manager sees a performance problem with the sales team. But the question forces them to ask: Is this a people problem (individual level)? A team problem (team level)? A process problem (organizational level)? A strategy problem (market level)? A business model problem (industry level)? An economic problem (macroeconomic level)?

The engineer sees a reliability problem with the motor. But the question forces them to ask: Is this a materials problem (chemistry level)? A component problem (motor level)? A system integration problem (device level)? A usage pattern problem (service level)? A maintenance infrastructure problem (ecosystem level)?

The answer determines what kind of innovation is needed and at what level intervention will be effective.

The answer determines what kind of innovation is needed and at what level intervention will be effective.

Great innovators embrace this question. They resist the natural tendency to attack the problem where it presents itself. They map the hierarchy. They trace constraints. They find the level where their intervention will have cascading effects rather than isolated impact.

Thomas Edison might have been the greatest inventor of the 19th century, but he failed at electrification because he answered this question wrong—he thought the problem lived at the component level (better filaments, better generators) when it actually lived at the system level (transmission infrastructure). Nikola Tesla succeeded because he understood that the motor was a component, but the system architecture was the leverage point.

Every domain you work in has this question buried within it. The most valuable innovation opportunities lie in finding where the true answer differs from the obvious answer.

FINAL THOUGHT

Systems thinking is not about complexity for its own sake. It's about seeing clearly where complexity actually exists and where simplicity is possible.

Find the reverse salients that hold back entire systems

The electric grid that powers your devices, the internet that connects your thoughts, the cities that organize your lives—all were created by people who saw nested hierarchies where others saw only parts.

Your task is to see the hierarchies in your domain and find where innovation can change not just a component, but a system.

HISTORICAL CONTEXT: THE CASE FOR NESTED HIERARCHIES

Success Story: Shell's Scenario Planning and Systems Understanding

In the early 1970s, Shell's planning group was grappling with uncertainty about the future of energy. Pierre Wack and his colleagues had developed scenario planning, but they found that scenarios alone weren't enough—they needed a way to understand how different futures would affect the entire system of energy production, distribution, and consumption.

What they developed was essentially nested hierarchies analysis applied to energy markets:

Level -2: Resources — Oil reserves, extraction costs, geology

Level -1: Technologies — Drilling, refining, transportation

Level 0: Production System — Wells, platforms, refineries, pipelines

Level +1: Energy Markets — OPEC, spot markets, contracts, pricing

Level +2: Industrial Economy — Manufacturing, transportation, heating

Level +3: Geopolitics — Middle East stability, US policy, Soviet production

Level +4: Global Development — Economic growth, population, urbanization

When the 1973 oil embargo hit, Shell was the only major oil company that wasn't blindsided. They had mapped how disruptions at Level +3 (geopolitics) would cascade through Level +1 (markets) and affect their position at Level 0 (production).

The hierarchy map didn't predict the future—but it showed them where in the system to watch for signals and where their interventions would have leverage.

Kodak's failure is often described as "missing digital photography." But the real failure was hierarchical blindness—an inability to see how changes at upper levels of the system were making their lower-level investments irrelevant.

Level -1: Components — Film emulsions, lenses, sensors

Level 0: Products — Cameras, film, printers

Level +1: Services — Photo finishing, retail distribution

Kodak's strategy focused on Levels -2 through +1. They actually invested billions in digital imaging technology at Levels -1 and 0. But they failed to see that the containing system (Level +2) was transforming:

What "photography" meant in 1990:

Capturing moments → printing them → storing physical albums → occasionally sharing

What "photography" was becoming by 2005:

Capturing constantly → sharing instantly → never printing → social identity expression

The entire PURPOSE of the Level +2 system was shifting from "memory preservation" to "social communication." No amount of excellence at Levels -1 to +1 could address a paradigm shift at Level +2.

Even worse, Kodak missed that a NEW level was emerging between their products and their customers: platforms (Facebook, Instagram, smartphone photo apps). By the time they recognized this level existed, it was already occupied by digital-native players.

The Lesson: If Kodak had systematically mapped their hierarchy and looked for shifts at upper levels, they would have seen that their carefully optimized lower levels were becoming irrelevant to a changing system purpose. Introduction

Map at least 3 levels above your central element with system characteristics at each level

Document the purpose, actors, dynamics, and boundaries at each level

Create a visual representation of your complete hierarchy

PHASE 3: CROSS-LEVEL ANALYSIS

Introduction

With your hierarchy mapped, Phase 3 focuses on the relationships between levels—the dependencies, flows, constraints, and dynamics that create both barriers and opportunities. This is where the real analytical insight emerges.

Phase 3 Objectives:

Map cross-level dependencies (what each level needs from and provides to adjacent levels)

Identify feedback loops that cross levels

Document constraints and bottlenecks at each level boundary

Identify reverse salients (rate-limiting constraints)

Locate potential leverage points

STEP 3.1: Cross-Level Dependency Mapping

Explanation

For each boundary between levels, document what flows across it and what dependencies exist. This reveals where the hierarchy is tightly coupled (changes cascade easily) versus loosely coupled (changes are absorbed).

Common Mistakes to Avoid

Mistake 1: Starting Too Low

The Problem: Beginning analysis at the component level and never adequately exploring containing systems. The Fix: Force yourself to map at least 3 levels above before concluding. Upper levels are usually where the most binding constraints hide.

Mistake 2: Confusing Components with Levels

aining systems. The Fix: Force yourself to map at least 3 levels above before concluding. Upper levels are usually where the most binding constraints hide.

Mistake 2: Confusing Components with Levels

The Problem: Listing many components at a single level and calling them different levels. The Fix: Each level must have different organizing principles, actors, and dynamics. If two things share these, they're at the same level.

Mistake 3: Ignoring Non-Technical Dimensions

The Problem: Mapping technical levels in detail while treating regulatory, economic, and social levels superficially. The Fix: Upper levels are usually dominated by non-technical factors. Give them equal analytical attention.

Mistake 4: Declaring a Reverse Salient Without Testing

The Problem: Identifying a visible problem and calling it a reverse salient without testing whether it's actually rate-limiting. The Fix: Apply all five reverse salient test questions. If solving it wouldn't unlock significant system progress, it's not the reverse salient.

Mistake 5: Generating Only Component-Level Opportunities

The Problem: Focusing opportunity generation on technical improvements without exploring system, ecosystem, or paradigm-level possibilities. The Fix: Force yourself to generate at least 3 opportunities at each level of the hierarchy.
